body.class_summary: Kimberly Azzarito teaches yoga in an approachable way to every BODY. She empowers her students by weaving yogic traditions, stories, and myths with dynamic movement and alignment on the mat and opens the narrative between body, breath, and mind through authentic expression.
body.name: Kimberly Azzarito
body.class_title: Yoga Mythology: A Journey to the Self through movement, breath, and the power of myth
body.bio:
Kimberly Azzarito teaches yoga in an approachable way to every BODY. She empowers her students by weaving yogic traditions, stories, and myths with dynamic movement and alignment on the mat and opens  the narrative between body, breath, and mind through authentic expression.

Kimberly believes in the deep power of storytelling. It’s the reason myths are passed down in all traditions and cultures. The telling of a story can bring us into alignment with inspiration, spark creativity, give insight into life’s challenges, touch the heart, and commission the soul. 

Being affected by Scoliosis in her early 20’s, Kimberly’s curved spine caused her great pain. In the early 1990s, Kimberly began her yoga journey. She learned that through a consistent practice, her scoliosis could be healed and painful knee injuries are now strengthened and stable. 
Kimberly received her 500 hr RYT through Shanti Yoga Teacher Training and believes that the key is to stay flexible in body, mind and spirit. She teaches the wisdom of Joseph Campbell, “the privilege of a lifetime is to be who you are.”

She leads group classes at Yoga Tree of Boise, Sage Yoga & Wellness and the Treasure Valley West Y. She also incorporates wellness programs for the State of Idaho employees. Kimberly believes a good teacher never stops being a student. The list of teachers that inspire her is long and she is full of gratitude towards each including  Dharma Mittra, Shiva Rea, Sianna Sherman, Jason Crandell, Leslie Kaminoff, Debbi Murphy, Max Strom, and Erich Schiffmann.

Everything is connected;  when we open to the practice of yoga on the mat, not only do our physical bodies become stronger and more supple but our minds become flexible, our hearts grow in empathic compassion, our creativity inspired and the remembrance that we are beings of light.

Workshop:
Thursday, 2-3 PM
Yoga Mythology: A Journey to the Self
A Journey to the Self through movement, breath, and the power of myth.

body.name: Amber Labelle
body.bio: Amber Labelle is the Local Boise Group Leader of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America (www.momsdemand.org), a non-partisan, grassroots movement of Americans demanding common-sense solutions to the gun violence that endangers our children, families, and communities.

body.name: Cactus Coy
body.bio: Cactus Coy is a project created by River Merrill and Janae Nilo, partners in life and songwriting.  Their debut EP, 'Dormant', was released on December 16, 2017.  The music is characterized by smooth folk melodies over mellow guitar parts and is described as very sleepy music.

body.name: The Future of Music in Advertising and Media
body.bio:
There isn’t a singular way to excel within the world of media — it’s a vast, marketable world with its twists and turns. In this ever-changing landscape where modern technology heavily influences campaigns and successful marketing outreach, what does this mean for agency creatives and musicians? Similarly, how does this affect the creation and application of music?

Our panel of creative agency insiders, artists, and music licensing experts will help us navigate through the over saturated world of media, while discussing music’s role in emerging and trending channels on the horizon.

body.name: Caitlin Lister
body.bio: Caitlin Lister served in the United States Marine Corps from 2004-2010. During her 6 years of service, she completed two tours of combat in Iraq, three years of US Embassy Guard Duty, and was honorably discharged as a Staff Sergeant. After the Marines, Caitlin earned her Bachelor’s Degree in Political Science at BSU. Caitlin is currently the Idaho State Senate Minority Caucus Chief of Staff and is finishing her MPA with an emphasis in Environmental and Natural Resource Policy Administration. She is married with two children.

body.name: Nnamdi Ogbonnaya
body.bio: NNAMDI OGBONNAYA is a multi-instrumentalist composer, producer, and performer. His musical identity was forged in the DIY community of Chicago. Relentless participation in numerous musical projects bridged genres and created inroads between scenes. Near constant activity quickly made him a locus of gravity in the community. Constant participation quickly opened channels to a broad cross-section of the arts world. Nnamdi has toured the USA, Mexico Europe and Canada with projects ranging from punk to jazz. A full accounting of his musical activity over the last eight years includes approximately 15 bands and dozens of tours. All the while, Nnamdi has not only released a stream of records and EPs under his name and the ironic moniker “Nnamdi’s Sooper Dooper Secret Side Project”, but also runs his own label called SOOPER Records. His solo styling combines hip-hop, experimental rock, gospel, and jazz. His songs can often contain a sense of satire that is just as humorous as it is critical. Nnamdi’s lyrical insights draw on the diversity of his cultural experience as a Black, Jewish, first generation Nigerian-American. His work is characterized by the coupling of sophisticated compositional structures with pop-music motifs.

body.name: Dante Elephante
body.bio: Dante Elephante based in Los Angeles, California. Released "German Aquatics" in 2013 & "Anglo-Saxon Summer" produced by Jonathan Rado in 2015 via Lolipop Records

body.name: Megan Williams
body.bio: Megan Williams is a hairy mama arts administratrix and poet. She makes literary things happen at The Cabin, a center for readers & writers. Once upon a time she received an MFA from Sarah Lawrence College and her poems appeared in journals like Tin House, PANK, Vinyl Poetry, etc. Now she mostly confronts her abiding nostalgia for LiveJournal at http://selfperformancewith.tumblr.com

body.name: Dan Bartlett / Defending Digital Democracy Project
body.bio: Dan Bartlett is an MPA candidate at the Harvard Kennedy School and is a U.S. government civil servant. Before entering the civil service, he served eight years active duty in the Marine Corps and deployed multiple times to Iraq and Afghanistan.

body.name: Dedicated Servers
body.bio:
The Gem State has been dedicated for 13 years and counting, and emcees MCMD & DTF show no signs of slowing down. The perspectives of the high school brethren have seasoned but the energy and attitude that set them apart from other performers remain. 

Separately and collectively venturing into new fields including Twitch gaming, DJ'ing, and solo projects, Dedicated Servers find their time together more important and valuable than ever, and aim to ignite the dormant energies that lie inside all of the Treefort attendees. 

Spanning sounds from traditional hip hop to futuristic grooves, Dedicated Servers have been known to harness the vibes of De La Soul, Atmosphere, Clipse, A Tribe Called Quest, Postal Service, and more. They've opened for Lupe Fiasco, Schoolboy Q, Mega Ran, Turbo T. Double, Dessa, Brother Ali, and Bone Thugs N Harmony, just to name a few.

What happened to having fun with music? This is the question the Dedicated Servers ask themselves every day, and they are determined to include YOU in their party! You're either DEAD or you're DEDICATED.

body.name: Ben Hansen
body.bio:
Ben Hansen was the lead host and investigator of the TV show "Fact or Faked: Paranormal Files" which originally aired three seasons on the Syfy Channel and now can be seen on Destination America. The Fact or Faked team investigated videos and photos of alleged paranormal events to determine if they had a natural explanation, were hoaxed, or if they remained unexplained.  In addition to responding to UFO cases, the six person team also led audiences around the world in search of ghosts, Bigfoot, chupacabras, mermaids, and other unusual occurrences.  More recently, Hansen has appeared on "Expedition Unknown" and "Mysteries of the Outdoors" on the Travel Channel and "Paranormal Lockdown and "Ghosts of Shepherdstown" on Destination America.  

Hansen graduated from the University of Utah with a degree in Sociology and Criminology.  He then went to work for several years investigating child physical abuse and sex crimes before moving on to employment in federal law enforcement.  He now uses the skills he learned in interviewing and investigation methodology to focus his research on techniques to validate UFO and other paranormal witness testimony and filter out hoaxers and cases with natural explanations.  As a night vision and thermal imaging equipment dealer, Hansen also works with technology manufacturers to improve low-light video recording with the goal of improving the documentation of the supernatural phenomenon.  His company, Night Vision Ops, can be found online at www.nightvisionops.com.

body.name: ROCCI JOHNSON BAND
body.bio: A more apt moniker there isn't. The frontperson of the eponymous group that has long been Humpin' Hannah's house band, Johnson is arguably the reigning queen of Boise's rock scene: For 30-plus years, she and her band have been raising the roof with booty-shaking cover songs four or five nights every week. The raspy-voiced rocker has a big heart and a strong work ethic and Johnson wants everyone who walks in the door to have as good a time as she's having, and she sure as hell knows how to throw a shindig. If she ever gets tired of rockin' out, she could make a killing as a party planner.  - Boise Weekly

body.name: Denim Casket
body.bio: Members of Microbabies, Memory Smoker & Deep Creeps. Our sound has been described as Cajun Ragu Dixieland Devereux's Old Timey Zing Zang Ragtime Dixieland Jazz. But we think we sound more punk than that.

body.name: Red Light Challenge
body.bio:
Red Light Challenge is a pop rock band made up of two high-energy, multi-instrumental brothers from Hawaii. Brothers Sean (25) and Kyle (20) Luster were born and raised on the island of Oahu, both graduated as valedictorian of their class, and have been playing music together for fun since they were kids. Although the band typically consists of two core members, they continue to create huge soundscapes both live and in the studio using their love for songwriting and their high-energy attitudes. The brothers have developed a unique sound coming from Hawaii, while being able to incorporate catchy Pop melodies, multi-part harmonies, R&B grooves, and Rock sensibilities into their music. 
 
The brothers from Red Light Challenge pride themselves on consistently delivering memorable live shows with songs the audience members can move to. Both their electric and acoustic set lists always contain dozens of original songs and a wide range of original takes on cover songs by artists such as The Beatles, Imagine Dragons, Bruno Mars, and many more. In addition to performing and recording, the band created and put on multiple events for “Red Light Challenge, Green Light Go”, a fun, student-interactive assembly program that empowers students to achieve their goals.
 
To expand beyond their Hawaii roots, the band self-booked a national tour performing at Six Flags Amusement Parks and major shopping malls in 2010. They threw out hundreds of Hawaiian leis and “Live Aloha” buttons, spreading Aloha at each stop. The brothers continued performing and writing music after this tour as Sean finished his undergraduate degree in 2013. After Sean graduated, the band self-booked a massive 42-show, 16-state Summer Tour spanning from Colorado to New England and back home to Hawaii.
 
In November of 2014, Red Light Challenge made history by being the first band from Hawaii to earn a Los Angeles Music Award, which took place at The Avalon Hollywood. There, they were presented the prestigious ‘Hot Adult Contemporary Artist of the Year’ award. While in Los Angeles, the band had the opportunity to meet Producer/Engineer Warren Huart (Aerosmith, The Fray, James Blunt, etc.), who wound up producing the band’s debut EP, “Lookout Mountain”, released in 2015.
 
After moving to Idaho in the summer of 2015 for Kyle to work toward his undergraduate degree and for Sean to attain his Masters, Red Light Challenge has organically grown a large fanbase in the city of Boise. The band has performed over 250 times since moving to Idaho in the summer of 2015. Additionally, in June of 2017, the brothers put a full 5-piece band together to start performing for larger events for bigger audiences. The band has already performed for Downtown Boise’s Alive After Five, Art in the Park, and at the Knitting Factory in Boise. Now, having rhythm guitar, drums, lead guitar, bass, keyboard, and multi-part harmonies in their arsenal, Red Light Challenge has plans to continue performing across the Pacific Northwest and record new music for radio and television throughout 2018.

body.name: Beyond Burgers and IPAs: Bringing More Adventurous Cuisine to Boise
body.bio: You can get a burger and an IPA at most restaurants in Boise. But when it comes to more adventurous cuisine, the list is decidedly smaller. Ask Boise restauranteurs and they'll say burgers and IPAs are their best-sellers. But ask Boise diners and they'll say they're hungry for more innovative options. Join panelists Dave Krick, owner of Boise's OG burger and beer palace Bittercreek; Kris Komori, James Beard nominated chef at seasonal prix-fixe powerhouse State & Lemp; sour beer evangelist Bre Hovley of Barbarian Brewing; and Cal Elliott, former Executive Chef at NYC's Michelin-starred Dressler and owner of Rye Restaurant in Williamsburg, as we tackle the question: How do we move beyond burgers and IPAs in Boise?

body.name: Kitty Crimes
body.bio:
What rapper and producer Kitty Crimes is most noted for are her flagrant performances. Crowd surfing is whatever if the wind is right, and live bravado just may be her strongest suit. She's opened for Big Freedia, Esme Patterson, Tennis, Andrew W.K., and has been featured by Red Bull, Red Rocks, and the Denver Post UMS. A Denver native and contributor to the city's musical landscape, she has previously fronted rock quartets, and drummed in an all-lady punk band, but found her stride writing, arranging, and performing as the unabashedly queer and wild identity of Kitty Crimes. 
Her newest release will feature what she's known for. Fast raps that sometimes are excessively explicit and an ensemble of multi-genre'd stabs at all the different expressions that pop has to offer.

body.name: Pussy Riot
body.bio: Nadya is a Russian musician, conceptual artist, and political activist. She’s the founder of the feminist punk collective, Pussy Riot, and has a history of political activism both in and out of the group. In Moscow in 2011, Pussy Riot began staging unauthorized provocative guerrilla performances in public locations, later editing footage of the performances into music videos, promoting gender equality, LGBT rights, and opposition to Russian President, Vladimir Putin. In 2012, she was convicted of “hooliganism motivated by religious hatred” after being arrested during a performance in Moscow Cathedral of Christ the Saviour. According to Vladimir Putin, the work “undermined the moral foundations of the Russian nation," sentencing Nadya and two others to two years’ hard labor in Siberia. She was recognized by the Russian human rights group “Union of Solidarity with Political Prisoners,” named a “prisoner of conscience due to the severity of the response of the Russian authorities” by Amnesty International, and received the LennonOno Grant for Peace in 2012. Her first collaboration with Dave Sitek (TV on the Radio, Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Kelis), “Chaika,” was released in February 2016, and her debut EP, “xxx”, came out on October 28.

body.name: Nelly Kate
body.bio: Playing within the territory of experimental pop, Nelly Kate layers heavy tones + beats with radio frequencies, field recordings, Casiotones, and deft lyrical/vocal arrangements. She has shared the stage with artists such as  tUnE-yArDs, Mirah, The Blow, Angel Olsen, and DIIV.

body.name: H-Hour
body.bio: Boise band from the early/ mid '80's. All original alternative rock.  Moved to Seattle in '86 with a bit of a new (heavier) direction. Having shared the bill with bands such as Sound Garden, Skin Yard, Faith No More, Green River and others. The band consists of Tad Doyle on drums, John Clint on vocals, Darren Peters on Bass, and Danny Brown on guitar

body.name: Nick Delffs
body.bio: http://www.mamabirdrecordingco.com/nick-delffs/

body.name: Hackfort Kick-off Party
body.bio: Super stoked about the lineup for Hackfort? What better way to immerse yourself into our programming than meeting your favorite speaker? Join us for our Hackfort Kick-off Party for beers, tunes provided by DJ Michna and the chance to meet your favorite game-boss, tech journalist or robot engineer! Must have a Hackfort Badge to attend.

body.name: Junior Rocket Scientist
body.bio: Grandson of a NASA engineer, Britt Glenn has been playing music with Brian Anglin as Junior Rocket Scientist for nearly 10 years now.  Ross Demastus joined the band on drums a couple years ago after a lovely mushroom hunt in the Redwoods and the trio have really clicked, both as friends and in crafting their own brand of space rock.  JRS released two early EP's (e3po and Lady Alice) as well as full length album Mu in 2016, and hope to record more new songs in 2018 for another release.

body.name: Sophie Hughes
body.bio: The charm of Sophie Hughes allows her to say and do things she shouldn't be able to get away with. Her good looks have helped her to achieve regular work as a voice actor. She has performed at Limestone Comedy Fest, 208 Comedy Fest, and Politically Re-Active with W. Kamau Bell and Hari Kondabolu.

body.name: Brett Netson
body.bio:
Spawned in Idaho’s Great Basin/Snake River Plain, Brett Netson specializes in heavy, psychedelic, lowdown rock and roll guitar/DMT therapist, Having served as an industrial grade force multiplier to the likes of Built to Spill,EARTH and cult rock outfit, Caustic Resin.  Netson joined Mark Lanegan’s touring band through 2005, hitting Europe and the US West Coast once or twice a year. Netson has also appeared on a few of Lanegan’s albums and EPs, as well as albums from Mike Johnson and the Evildoers, Helvetia, the Delusions and others. More recently, Netson appeared as a second guitarist on Earth’s critically acclaimed  album, Primitive and Deadly, and Nate Hall’s (USX) solo release, Electric Vacuum Roar and on the soon to be released Drought Stick by Gridfailure and Earth, Live at Third Man Records.

  Displaying a wilder, darker, more hedonistic sound than Built To Spill, Caustic Resin released six metal, space rock and psychedelia influenced albums between 1993 and 2003. Among them, 1998's The Medicine Is All Gone, has been described as, “the best record to come down off acid to…” a hallucinogenic, heavy guitar album almost without equal, has been reissued on Netson's own Scavenger Cult records.

 With the latest incarnation of the Netsonian under world exploration, he has scaled it down with the recent acquisition of the Moog Taurus bass synth pedal unit. Massive bass waves and stereo guitar, enabling a nimble path of navigation through the collective unconcious. The newest analog effort The SNAKES/CROSSS split will see release on LP and cassette through Scavenger Cult on October 6th.


Video Links: https://www.youtube.com/watch? v=mbLSPWaf-JY
                   https://www.youtube.com/watch? v=4VwHmtg74Gg
Press Links:  http://www.earsplitcompound.co m/site/2017/06/13/snakes-cross s-split-lp-to-see-release-via- brett-netsons-scavenger-cult-l abel/
                    http://cityworldnews.com/guita rist-brett-netson-lsd-intervie w/

body.name: Crystal Ghost
body.bio: Crystal Ghost is the project of Los Angeles based artist Elliott Baker, whose modern sensibilities work in tandem with a penchant for the retro groove, creating a synthesis that is undeniably unique and tasty. Baker brings us a brooding breed of disco, with a throbbing bass underlying vocals somehow both airy and stylishly mechanical. The sound is at once nostalgic and futuristic, making me long for an unremembered past while still remaining optimistic that I can perhaps, through music such as this, experience it afresh in the future.

body.name: Jordan Thornquest
body.bio:
Jordan Thornquest is a punk-influenced alt-rocker from Twin Falls, Idaho. His live band consists of Eli Stonemets (on a way nicer rhythm guitar), Chase Chandler (bass, much better voice), & Patrick Henry (drums, worth more than the car they'll arrive in).

Jordan’s debut EP released on December 1st, 2017: it’s called Late Bloomer. In it, Jordan talks about his struggle with self-identity, incapacity to maintain healthy relationships, burning down Twin Falls, and how he’s trying to make sure he doesn’t kill his poor dog. It has guitars in it, congas at one point, and laptop fans in the background. 

Rad.

body.name: Lux Groove
body.bio:
Born and raised in a small suburban town in Connecticut Lux Groove always had a passion for music at a very young age. During his early teenage years he got his first set of turntables and started to teach himself to DJ, heavily influenced by DJ's such as Jazzy Jeff, A-trak, Craze, and Qbert he quickly he become engulfed in the turntablism scene, doing showcase performances and entering local DJ battles as well as the DMC's. 

Lux Groove began to experiment with other genres of music which led him into house music, and wanted to be more than just a DJ. Very influenced by Justin Martin and other Dirtybird Record members Lux Groove began to start producing and after a short period of time had his first EP called "From The Back" which is now signed to Worthy's Anabatic record label. Releasing with record labels such as Dirtybird, This Ain't Bristol, Perfect Driver, Sounds of Sumo has proven that his dedication and success will continue.  Lux Groove has performed along side and shared the stage with Kill Frenzy, Worthy, Weiss, Christian Martin, and many more. Lux Groove is sure to continue to produce bass driven forward thinking house music and also his live performances are sure to rock any crowd, putting to use his heavy turntablism background mixed in with his style of bass house music. Expect to hear much more coming from Lux Groove.

body.name: Kyle Emerson
body.bio:
Denver-based singer-songwriter Kyle Emerson is pleased to announce the release of his debut album, and single of the same name, Dorothy Alice. Dorothy Alice is the full-length follow-up to his EP “Worth It,” named one of 2017’s Best Colorado Albums by Colorado Public Radio’s Open Air. Emerson began writing the album when he found himself down and out in LA; his band had broken up, his relationship was falling apart, and he was sleeping in his car.  When he received the news that a dear loved one had passed away, he knew it was time for a drastic move.

	Emerson packed up and moved back to Colorado, where he found his footing and completed the album full of swift fingerpicking, tell-all lyrics, the slickness of LA and the earnestness of Colorado. Emerson’s music has been compared to the likes of Big Thief, Elliot Smith, and Andy Shauf. The live band features members of Paper Bird, Plum, Shady Elders, and Bad Licks. He and his band has shared the stage with the likes of Charles Bradley, Twin Peaks, The Districts, Will Butler (of Arcade Fire), Jeff the Brotherhood, La Luz, and many more.

body.name: Callie Rose Ritter - Élan Vital
body.bio:
Callie Ritter is a formerly New York based choreographer and dancer. Her piece Élan Vital, which will be performed to live sound design, is about growth in the context of humans and machines 

The piece's concept was ignited when watching a video of a machine flop around on a table for four days until it learned how to 'walk'. What is it, that is evolving in humans and machines, and where is it going? Callie will attempt to discover this answer with her movement.

body.name: Throes
body.bio: We play heavy music that serves as an outlet for our creativity and frustrations.

body.name: Ola Sweet
body.bio:
Boise-based Ola Sweet make no apologies for their love of big loud guitars. "The Thick Sound" is what fans have come to call the analog stew that constitutes the ingredients in Ola Sweet's vintage-inspired sound that may just be more classic rock than self-proclaimed indie rock. But don't let their fundamental rock roots lead you to believe their big reverby vocals and fuzz-forward guitar tones are anything less than comfortable in a playlist shuffle next to The Black Keys, The Dig or My Morning Jacket.

Freshly acquainted in 2015, JJ Martinsen (vocals, guitar) and Brandon Wallace (guitar, keys) found themselves on common ground as recent Idaho transplants; leaving former bands behind in Richmond, VA and Seattle, WA, respectively. Martinsen's classic, soulful vocal style was an immediate click with Wallace's super-sized overdriven soundscapes.

Fuzz-forward guitar, big reverby vocals. Lyrics always searching with abandon and curiosity. Sometimes odd, always haunting. The result is a unique blend of searing blues rock carelessly littered with pop-rich hooks.

body.class_summary:
The Boise Spirit Community will have a presence at Yogafort in several ways:
*Panel Discussion - Spirituality vs. Religion: Finding the Sacred in the 21st Century
*Sanctuary in the MOVE Studio at JUMP
*Spirit Dome concerts on the JUMP lawn
body.name: The Boise Spirit Community
body.class_title: The Boise Spirit Community is a multi-faith initiative that celebrates the medium of music, meditation, and movement to enliven the spirit, nourish the mind, and sustain the body.  Its members come from a wide swath of faith and spiritual groups throughout the Treasure Valley and beyond, celebrating life under one tent, open to all, ensuring anyone a place at the table.
body.bio:
The Boise Spirit Community is a multi-faith initiative that celebrates the medium of music, meditation, and movement to enliven the spirit, nourish the mind, and sustain the body.  Its members come from a wide swath of faith and spiritual groups throughout the Treasure Valley and beyond, celebrating life under one tent, open to all, ensuring anyone a place at the table.

Description:

Sanctuary in the Move Room Friday - Sunday: The Sanctuary welcomes everyone. It is a place to be still, offer prayers, and join in meditative classes led by diverse voices of the Boise Community. Please come and contribute to our sacred space, find a place to rest and decompress from festival life.

Panel in the Inspire Room: Spirituality vs. Religion: Finding the Sacred in the 21st Century: Americans, particularly younger generations, are staying away from institutional religion and instead choosing multiple spiritual and religious sources. The numbers of self-identified “spiritual but not religious” are rapidly increasing and traditional institutional religion finds itself at a potential turning point. As spiritual seekers are taking the lead in shaping a new faith in America, join a diverse panel of seekers, religiously faithful, and those in between as they explore questions like, Are religion and spirituality the same? Can you be spiritual but not religious? Is spirituality the new religion and what can traditional religious institutions learn from sustained engagement with spiritual seekers?

The Spirit Dome Friday - Sunday: The Spirit Dome celebrates the musical traditions of the mutli-faith groups represented in the Boise Spirit Community. We offer 40 minute musical offerings on the hour from 10 am to 6 pm.

body.name: Crona Clone
body.bio: Mid Tempo to fast paced hard hitting electronic music that is focused on bringing melodies and intense synthesis together. Bouncing back and forth from Ambient to hard hitting bass lines with magical leads.

body.name: Tocaio
body.bio:
‘Organic electronic’ is the term that Texas native, Hector Carlos Ramirez, uses to describe the music he creates as Tocaio. At an early age, Ramirez showed deep rooted interest in music, finding inspiration by attending and organizing local shows in his hometown of Laredo, Texas. It wasn't until 2013, however, that Ramirez would find himself beginning to experiment with ambient and electronic music after relocating to Austin, Texas to attend film school at the University of Texas. Currently based in Los Angeles, California, Tocaio draws inspiration by experimenting with loop / effect pedals and synthesizers in his bedroom studio. "The music is a soothing and wonderfully ambient affair incorporating field recordings of crackling fires, delicate beats along with live instrumentation. In parts, it sounds like Vangelis with a soul." 
   2017 saw the release of Tocaio's debut LP, "Pointillism" on Noise Revolt Records. The debut LP contains 13 unique and eclectic tracks Ramirez refers to as "13 separate soundscapes." Known for incorporating live instruments into his live performances, Tocaio takes a different approach to creating and performing electronic music and ultimately, attempts to bridge the gap between electronic producers and rock bands.

body.name: Cameron Crow, Kount
body.bio: Cameron Crow is a Senior Business Intelligence Analyst responsible for solving problems with data. He has experience successfully driving business outcomes in a range of departments (Product, Marketing, Sales, Client Success, Account Management, Finance) and in a range of industries (Software, Environmental, Government, Education).

body.name: Zee Will
body.bio: Next generation hip-hop. He performs w/ a live band or DJ.  Poetic approach and raw talent. Drive, determination with a lyrical edge. In 2012 he won multiple talent shows to earn the right to open for Kendrick Lamar. He has shared the stage w/ Rakim, Freddie Gibbs, Black Milk, Dizzy Wright, Slum Village, Fashawn, Saba, ilovemakonnen.

body.name: Brooke Would
body.bio:
She's been weaving together others art into textiles all her own for lifetimes now but in this one she has always been focused on funk. She bought her first records in 1998 when trance took over and she was curious if the house vibes of parties past still existed.

Brooke's lovingly curated sound can be identified with eyes closed by those who know. You can count on some deep energy that starts in the hips, and moves to the heart.

body.name: Urban Worm Farm
body.bio: The Urban Worm Farm is a vermiculture (worm composting) operation located in the basement of Bittercreek Alehouse and Red Feather Lounge in the heart of downtown Boise and will be emerging into the sunshine at Kidfort! Amy Lyons, Director of optimism, Official Worm Momma, and Worm Wrangler Extraordinaire, will be sharing her candid enthusiasm as she discusses her beloved squirm of a colony, the practice and value of composting with worms, as well as the great impact worms make in the world around us. Stop by for a pop-in experience or join us for a more extended experience at our Kidfort workshop on Sunday, 3/25.

body.name: Sonny Smith
body.bio:
For years, Sonny Smith has built his own brand of indie-folk and rock & roll, growing into a cult favorite along the way. To those who know his work, he's an incredibly prolific creator, with a dozen albums to his name and a handful of related projects — including multiple stage plays, a full-length musical and his nationally-recognized art installation, "100 Bands" — under his belt. A longtime fixture of San Francisco's arts scene, he's managed to fly just beneath the mainstream's radar for decades, while still releasing a string of acclaimed records with labels like Fat Possum and Polyvinyl.

On his newest record, Rod For Your Love, he gets back to basics. Produced by Black Keys frontman Dan Auerbach and recorded in Nashville, Rod For Your Love roots itself in old-school, guitar-fueled rock & roll. These are love songs built for the garage and the dance floor, with big-hearted melodies and thick harmonies. It's the stuff you might've heard in the 1960s, back when groups like the Kinks and the Velvet Underground were making left-field pop songs that celebrated the form while still bending the rules. With stacked vocal harmonies that sweep their way throughout the track list, Rod For Your Love nods to the past while still moving forward. It's a classic-sounding album that still belongs to the 21st century.

Released on Auerbach's new label, Easy Eye Sound, Rod For Your Love was recorded at the end of a cross-country tour. Smith and his band were firing on all cylinders, their rough edges sanded down by weeks of nightly shows. Meanwhile, 10 new songs had been written. Smith, who'd fallen in love all over again with his roles as a bandleader and frontman, didn't want to produce the tunes himself in a home studio. He wanted to focus on the music. Having heard that the Arcs, Auerbach's side-project, had covered one of his own songs during their own tour, Smith reached out to the Black Keys singer. Connections were made, studio time was booked, and Smith wound up finishing that countrywide tour in Nashville, where he and his road band tracked the album at Auerbach's studio.

The goal? To shine a light on the songs and the band, without many overdubs or assorted clutter.

"I think a lot of albums are made in reaction to the one that came directly before," says Smith. "My last record, Moods Baby Moods, was very layered and used a lot of drum machines. I was making weird sounds with synths. By the time we got to Nashville and began working with Dan, I was thinking 'Let's just make a fun, guitar-driven record. I don't want to have any extracurricular stuff here. I just want it to be really pure.'"

The lyrics follow suit. A personal album filled with heart-of-sleeve songwriting, Rod For Your Love looks inward. It's autobiographical. Fittingly, it's also Sonny Smith's first solo album in years, following a string of records billed under his band's name, Sonny and the Sunsets. "I'm writing about myself now, and not the people around me," he explains. "It felt right to make it a solo record."

body.name: Katherine Carole (aka KC Nova)
body.bio: Previously named Kc Nova, She has recently changed her name after numerous life changes to Katherine Carole. Always playing tech house and techno for the fun of it and in pursuit of the love of dance. This local Boisean has been in the music scene for almost a decade and doesn't plan to quit boosting her community.

body.name: Dance Around the World
body.bio:
Enjoy the sights and sounds of dance from around the world! We have unique, diverse, and culturally rich performances to showcase how awesome dance culture is near and far. We can't fit the whole world into one hour, but these five countries are a start!
Featuring live dancers from:
Open Arms Dance Company, 
Ballet Folklorico - Mexico Lindo
Irish Dance Idaho
Shimi Tree Flamenco Dancers
Oinkari Basque Dancers

body.name: Coin-Counting: How to Diversify Your Crypto-Index
body.bio: Local data genius Cameron Crow (Kount) has developed a solid system for figuring out when to buy/sell one of the many cryptocurrencies that currently exist and he’s going to share his ‘trade’ secret.

body.name: Caitlin James
body.bio: Caitlin James is a singer song-writer based in Nashville, Tennessee. With two moves she has been gathering and collecting, first to California and then the wind eventually blew her east to Tennessee. All the while she has been writing heart-achy and memorable melodies with her Gibson Hummingbird, Pearl. She carries with her an open heart, made wild from her upbringing in Idaho.

body.name: Storyfort Presents The Odyssey VS Death Rattle: A Ballet
body.bio: This special Storyfort crossover event presents Death Rattle writers Diana Forgione, Alex Yann, and Dig Reeder as they revisit the tales of The Odyssey to create original works of poetry and fiction which will culminate in a live reading, followed by the performance of three short contemporary ballets based on the work choreographed by Daniel Ojeda of Ballet Idaho, Lydia Sakolsky-Basquil of Project Flux, and independent choreographer Selby Jenkins, an affiliate of Idaho Dance Theatre and Project Flux.

body.name: Clinton Herrick and Heather Meuleman
body.bio:
By day, Clinton Herrick makes ends meet any way he can -- handyman jobs, detailing cars or designing furniture. But nighttime is when Clinton really gets to display his many talents: He's the hot headliner in an all-folk revue. Clinton sees potential in a 19-year-old he dubs the Kid (Heather Meuleman), takes the teen under his wing and instructs him (her?) in the tricks of the trade. However, Clinton learns there's a downside to the songwriters lifestyle when it threatens his romance with the Kid's sister. (also loosly based off Magic Mike)

With a decade of entertaining under their cuffs, Clinton and Heather are original members of Portland's mythical folk project The Jackalope Saints and Treefort music fest veterans. As Saints and members of local folk project Thistledown and The Pan Handles, they've played Northwest String Summit, Mogo Music Festival, and Sawtooth Valley Gathering, and shared stages with such acts as the Infamous String Dusters, Jeff Austin Band, Hot Buttered Rum, California Honeydrops,  Hot Buttered Rum, Joe Pug, Shook Twins and the Jay Cobb Anderson Band.  Make sure to tune in and see what tricks this reunited duo has in their hats for Treefort 2018.

body.name: The Seatopians
body.bio: Originally hailing from 50 kilometers below the ocean floor, The Seatopians now call Boise home and are bringing their unique style of energetic surf rock to the local music scene. Come for the face-melting guitar riffs and walls of reverb; stay for the sci fi B movie references.

body.name: Dear Nora
body.bio:
Dear Nora’s fingerprints can be seen all over the contemporary music landscape, from the off-the-cuff lyrical ingenuities of Frankie Cosmos to the plaintive intimacy of Girlpool, who even name-checked the project in a song on their debut album. Katy Davidson started the band over 15 years ago in Portland and, before retiring the name in 2008, released three perfect full-lengths — 2001’s We’ll Have A Time, 2004’s Mountain Rock, and 2006’s There Is No Home — and countless 7″ and one-offs, most of which were collected on the Three States: Rarities 1997-2007 compilation. She also toured the world over with a rotating cast of band members, bringing her Pacific Northwest folk across the globe.

Davidson kept making music after hanging up the Dear Nora hat, as Lloyd & Michael and Key Losers, but she reunited Dear Nora in early 2017 in celebration of a reissue of Mountain Rock, her favorite of the band's albums. It was released on vinyl on 1/13/17 via Orindal Records, the label started by Casiotone For The Painfully Alone’s Owen Ashworth. [Since then, she has recorded a brand new Dear Nora album which will be released in early 2018.] 

-James Rettig, Stereogum

body.name: Cloudest Speaker

song.title: Emperors Clouds & Mist ft. St. Terrible

body.bio: Produced in the bedroom of Jens's space in Ketchum, ID, Cloudest Speaker, inspired by the sky, his music is enhanced by his own experiential highs. He journeys through raw, gritty soundscapes and beat heavy compositions, thus creating transcending ambient melodies that take you to another place...mostly outer space.

body.name: Maria Santana
body.bio: Maria was born in San Sebastian El Grande, Jalisco. She grew up in Nampa, ID. Maria is a legal assistant at an immigration law firm. As a DACA recipient Maria knows the struggle of being undocumented. Maria has been surrounded by a lot of nice, hardworking undocumented people. She loves working at an immigration law firm because she gets to help people make their dream come true when they are finally able to obtain legal status in the U.S. Maria would like to be able to continue with her education so one day she herself could become an immigration attorney.

body.name: Dance Battle
body.bio:
Want to dance? Come to the Nest (12th & Grove) and sign up at 12:30 on Sunday! The battle begins at 1:00! The Kidfort Dance Battle follows a tournament style, one versus one format and the top competitors leave with a prize! (age brackets - pre-K -2nd grades, 3rd-6th grades & 7th-12th grades)
Lead by Khoa Nuguyen the Kidfort Dance Battle will be epic! Dance battles are a competition. That doesn’t mean it’s all serious though! Competitions themselves are a good chance for dancers to showcase their own style. Win or lose, all dancers should feel hungry to grow more and work harder. Everyone is connected through dance and music so it brings people together to form a tight community. The most important part is having fun by either watching dancers exchange or being a part of that exchange. That being said, audiences at a dance battle event are participating by giving feedback and energy to the dancers who in turn give energy back.

body.name: SISTERS
body.bio:
“A revolution without dancing is not a revolution worth having" is a quote famously attributed to Author Emma Goldman. These words could be the motto of Emily Westman and Andrew Vait; better known as pop duo SISTERS.  

Wait Don't Wait is the band’s second full-length album (October, 2017) – and their first release via Tender Loving Empire.  Their debut LP, Drink Champagne (February, 2017) was met with a confluence of, “How were you able to release such a happy record right now?” and, “Thank you so much for releasing such a happy record right now!”; sentiments that are only amplified, strengthened and refined on Wait Don't Wait. 

March of 2017 in a cabin outside of Clinton, Washington: Westman and Vait hole up for a week.  Each day, they improvise from dawn until dusk as the cornerstones of songs emerge.  Each thread is built upon – developed with care, knowledge, and - most obviously - the joy of discovery.  As their time on the island draws to a close, the duo sits atop a quorum of tunes - enough to fill a record. 

April of 2017 at Different Fur Studios; San Francisco, California:  Westman and Vait contact producer and studio owner, Patrick Brown, (Toro y Moi, K. Flay, The Morning Benders) to discover that a last-minute opening at the studio happens to coincide with the only open days in the musicians’ schedules.  The duo take residence at the studio for 10 days in April; eating, sleeping, tracking and mixing at the recording house that has hosted projects by Herbie Hancock, David Byrne, Stevie Wonder, Jonathan Richman, Earth Wind & Fire, and far too many others to mention.

Utilizing the studio’s vast repository of vintage instruments, a borrowed baritone saxophone, and a few instruments brought from home, Westman and Vait lay down the 12 tracks.  Westman hops on the drum kit while Vait and engineer Bobby Renz look on from the control room.  Tape rolls; Westman pounds out the rhythm while Vait slices away on one of the dozens of synths within arm’s reach.  Brown pops his head in, listens, nods; someone makes a joke, everyone laughs and on to the next.  Before any memories can be cemented, the twelve tracks are complete.  Brown uses his wizardly mixing chops to cull the depth and breadth of the performances to the forefront, pumps up the bounce and sweetens the sheen.  The - albeit short - wait is over, and Wait Don't Wait is the resultant document; replete with catchy, quirky corkers overflowing with joy. 

With the release of Wait Don't Wait, SISTERS are not only presenting another pop record full of bangers that demands repeat listens – they are also methodically working toward creating a world that is safe for everyone.  The thing called hatred; the thing called violence; the things that threaten life and love cannot survive in the face of true joy. SISTERS deliver unrestrained joy, and it is desperately needed right now. The world has been waiting, but it needs wait no more.

body.name: Easter Island
body.bio:
Easter Island is fronted by Ethan Payne, a videographer and boom operator who has worked extensively in the television and film industries and Ryan Monahan (from Cindy Wilson of The B-52's solo project and Monahan, Ryan's eponymous solo endeavor).The band's new recordings also feature contributions from a number of respected Georgia musicians including Ethan's brother Asher Payne, Nathan Thompson, John Swint (currently of Yip Deceiver, formerly of Modern Skirts) on drums and percussion, and Slade Adams (formerly of Oak House and who has recorded with Cindy Wilson) and David Van Wyk (Bill Mallonee and the Vigilantes of Love, Jim White) on strings. 


The band has been working in secret quarters over the past three years. Although the band announced their breakup in 2014, Monahan and Payne began writing and recording new material only weeks later. Engineered and produced by Monahan, the band has traveled as far as Japan to work on the new songs and to film material for upcoming music videos, which should be released in early summer. The songs also received additional engineering, mixing, and mastering from Mike Albanese (who performs with Maserati, Cinemechanica, and Bit Brigade) at Espresso Machine Recording in Athens. 


Between 2010 and 2014, Easter Island performed at a number of festivals such as SXSW in Austin and CMJ in New York City. The band also received favorable press from Paste Magazine on a number of occasions, PopMatters, The Knife Fight and several other national publications. The song "Proud" from 2012's Frightened was licensed for the ABC series "Off the Map" and other songs from the band's catalog have been featured on other nationally broadcast television shows.

body.name: Super Sparkle
body.bio: A Spokane super group retro pop band featuring members from Cathedral Pearls, Water Monster, Scott Ryan and more. Super Sparkle formed in 2016 as a songwriting experiment between Karli Ingersoll, Max Harnishfeger and Scott Ryan Ingersoll. Ever since, the band has been creating dancey, singable pop oriented tunes that are equally well-written and crowd pleasing. Now with backup dancers and new collaborations, Super Sparkle's ultimate goal is to reach people and make them feel something big.

body.name: Wild Root Cafe & Market
body.bio:
Chefs Anne Marie and Michael Trebbi

Dish: Vegan Nourish Bowl with Zursun Beans, Ohana No Till Farm, and Shoots and Greens veggies. Meat option includes smoked Double R Ranch short ribs.

Bios:
Chef Michael Trebbi has worked in a kitchen for close to 30 years, starting as a kid helping out with prep work in his parent’s Italian restaurant. While he was in culinary school, he was wooed into his first chef gig. Since then, he has worked at a variety of food establishments, both in the Midwest, and more recently in Boise. 

Speaking of wooing, Michael did just that with Anne-Marie, while they were in culinary school together. After graduation and their wedding, she worked in corporate food service. She also did some stints in event planning before going back to school to study nutrition. In late 2015, Michael and Anne-Marie decided to further test their marital resolve, and opened Wild Root Café & Market.

1.) What is your favorite Idaho Ingredient?
Morels

2.) What is your favorite Idaho Beverage?
Idaho Kombucha Elderberry Rosehipster and Telaya Cabernet Sauvignon

3.) What is your favorite spice?
Salt or Gochujang

4.) What Treefort experience are you looking forward to most?
People watching!

body.name: Horse Feathers
body.bio:
Some quick true/false facts about the band Horse Feathers and their new album, So It Is With Us:

1. The record was partially recorded in a barn in a beautiful pastoral setting in rural Oregon
(true, but hasn’t everybody done this now?)

2. The band lives in Portland, OR
(also true, and they are consciously and unconsciously living breathing stereotypes just like the ones portrayed in Portlandia)

3. Horse Feathers last album charted on Billboard by selling fewer records than they had in the past
(true, but maybe more a comment on the music industry as a whole?)

4. For this album, the band was influenced by the following: Pentangle, Talk Talk, Paul Simon, The Band, Van Morrison, John Wesley Harding era Bob Dylan, Desire era Bob Dylan, and Abner Jay (not what you would have guessed, right?)ertainly tried to change things a bit.

body.name: Benoit Pioulard
body.bio: Since a young age, Thomas Meluch (Benoit Pioulard) has been fascinated by natural sounds and the textures of decay.  Starting with his first cassette recorder at the age of eight he has been creating unique sonic environments that are rich with harmony, accented by field recordings and found sound.  He has written and produced six full-lengths for the Portland, OR-based Kranky label, and has collaborated with the likes of Rafael Anton Irisarri (The Sight Below) and Kyle Bobby Dunn.

body.name: Sun Blood Stories
body.bio:
Sun Blood Stories is a mass of harmonic noise distilled into occasionally delicate, but always haunting songs. The band is comprised of three (3) equal members: Amber Pollard, Ben Kirby, and Jon Fust; this current arrangement is the realization of a sedulous refining process that has guided them into trio form.

Sun Blood Stories has been called “high desert psychedelia,” (thanks Wolvserpent) sonically compared to early Pink Floyd (thanks random patron at Hogan’s), and flatteringly referred to as “Neil Young in a cave on acid.” (thanks Talkative).

Sun Blood Stories is dreamy, aware, personal, open, fuzzed out, and loud af.

body.name: Whereling
body.bio: Whereling are a Boise based indie rock band with an affinity for the melancholic. Comprised of the reunited lineup of the defunct post-hardcore band, Reverie, Whereling forgoes Reverie’s aggression and settles in contemplative, wistful, and occasionally dream-like soundscapes. Their upcoming EP “Leaves” is scheduled for release spring of 2018.

body.name: Catskills
body.bio:
Nestled in the picturesque bosom of Northeast Oregon's Grande Ronde Valley-- a place where one might see a wolf driving a hybrid, or a hippie eating a steak-- schemes a four-piece psych rock outfit know as Catskills. Through barren winter doldrums, the squinty-eyed summer, pornographic spring, and a purely Tarkus fall, these men scour the far corners of the valley of peace for clues as to why the American quilt unravels so, and to whom praise and blame is intended, or earned?

What began as a dark, curious endeavor by prolific songwriter Gregory Rawlins and the creepy multi-instrumentalist Jeff Grammer immediately exploded into something like a chariot driven by the Headless Horseman once percussive virtuoso Andy Steele arrived in La Grande in late 2013. The final corner of this golden tablet was sealed when the stoic, and extra cool Wayne Marvin Callahan, or simply, 'Wayner' returned from an unforeseen sabbatical to Wisconsin. Wayner wanks bass.

2015 was the year of the Strike Anywhere EP, including a twelve-minute drum solo textured beneath a reading of  'A Study of Moths,' by award-winning poet David Axelrod.

The following year came 'Rufus Dufur,' the band's full-length debut, recorded in two days by Bart Budwig in Enterprise, Oregon and subsequently released on legendary Curly Cassettes out of Portland. This album continues to chart new territory for the band, growing more conceptualized and cinematic, with one particular track that eclipses the 16-minute mark. In Rufus contains elements of punk, doom, ambient soundscapes, interludes, overtures, instrumentals, one gigantic, glorious wind chime, and of course, good old stinky garage rock.

Their sophomoric effort, General Consensus (a reference to the pseudo-fictitious war criminal of the same name) is set for recording in early 2018.

body.name: Foodfort Meat Up
body.bio:
Join fellow carnivores as they converge on the Foodfort tent for the inaugural Meat Up, a fangs-out feast featuring special guest chefs Hugh Acheson (Five & Ten/Athens, GA), Carlo Lamagna (Magna/Portland, Ore.) and Brad Taylor (BBQ4LIFE/Boise).

In addition to piling your plate high with grilled Snake River Farms American Wagyu, Filipino-style pork and Kurobuta spare ribs, you can also sip on a boozy Buffalo Trace bourbon cocktail, a glass of Split Rail wine or a mouth-puckering specialty sour from New Belgium. Tickets for the Foodfort Meat Up are $40 and include two drink tokens.

body.name: Lakoda
body.bio: Lakoda is an alternative rock band from the Pacific Northwest whose sound has been described as a “mix of cage the Elephant-meets-early-Red Hot Chili Peppers- meets unadulterated rock.” (nanobotrock.com). The band is currently in the studio recording their upcoming EP, set for release in 2018. “There’s little doubt that if the band stays on this path they are destined for much bigger things.” (northwestmusicscene.net).

body.name: Black Kaweah
body.bio: Black Kaweah's compositionally expansive folk music is characterized by a strange dark sound accompanied by dynamic instrumentation and startling shifts in tempo.

body.name: Partner
body.bio:
Partner is the "mature" effort of two best friends named Josée Caron and Lucy Niles. Borne of their bizarre and fortuitous friendship, Partner confidently harnesses the infinite power of Rock to explore a variety of niche yet strangely universal themes. Self described as post-classic-rock.

Influenced by acts as varied as Melissa Etheridge, Ween, kd lang, and Prince, Partner delivers a refreshing and vital twist on a classic, prompting you to re-think what you thought was possible in Rock. 

Formed in Sackville NB, Partner relocated to Windsor ON at the beginning of 2016.  After a freakishly productive year of writing, recording, and touring, Partner have released their debut to the world, titled In Search of Lost Time (September 08, 2017). Their enthusiastic and action-packed live set has led to them being named the "best new band in Canada" in the Globe and Mail, and huge praise from NPR, Stereogum, Pitchfork, Noisey, VICE, Playboy and more.

Partner is genre-defying and terrifying: part musical act, part teenage diary, and 100% queer.

body.name: Jack Spallone, Ujo Music
body.bio:
Jack Spallone comes from a diversified background working in music and tech. Starting his career in music launching the careers of two Billboard artists, Jack's attention turned to exploring alternative methods for maintaining a career as a musician.

For the past four years, Jack has explored money transmission in digital IP supply chains and their applicability with decentralized, shared infrastructure. Today, Jack drives the product vision for Ujo Music building open source, service, and application level architecture for programmatic licensing and royalty management for the music business.

twitter: @jackspallone

body.name: Michael Hassoldt
body.bio:
Michael Hassoldt is a writer of fiction, non-fiction, and poetry. He lives in Meridian, Idaho,
and is a fourth-year writing student at Boise State University. His work has appeared in
various literary magazines. Michael is an Army veteran and retired police officer. His
writing centers on his experiences in the military and in the streets, where violence and
death colored his worldview a bit darker. But, even in the dark hope shines through.

body.name: Adam Jones
body.bio: Once the front man of the now deceased Boise band Hollow Wood, Adam has begun his new project under his own name. Adam was born and raised in Boise although for the past two years has been establishing a life in LA. He offers a unique style of catchy melodies often with dark undertones.

body.name: Brooke Lacey, KidBuildIt
body.bio: Brooke founded Tech Savvy, LLC - the only woman-owned and operated computer repair business in the Pacific Northwest, helping customers with everything from building custom gaming computers to cleaning up a slow PC.  KidBuildIt was created out of a community need for complete computer science instruction that included not only computer programming but computer hardware knowledge as well. Over the past ten years, Brooke has been closely involved with hundreds of programs, providing invaluable community education and raising awareness about the need for STEM education in Idaho.  Brooke also works closely with the Idaho STEM Action Center, the Governor’s initiative to facilitate implementation of important STEM programs, increasing STEM awareness throughout Idaho.

body.name: Gipsy Moonrise
body.bio: What an evolving cast of musicians, Gipsy Moonrise has grown into a rock and roll band that will not stop bringing it every time they hit the stage. This year they have a new batch of songs that have been politically charged, taking over topics like war and thoughts about breaking down walls instead of building them.

body.name: Encoded Notes: The Future of Blockchain & Music
body.bio: Spallone, founder of Ujo Music will be hosting an open dialogue about Bitcoin, blockchain, and what this technology means for musicians.

body.name: Dirt Fishermen
body.bio: An amalgamation of Cowboy Junkies, R.E.M., Sugarcubes, and Mudhoney, local yokels who wrote quirky original songs and milked 17 minutes of fame from our allotted 15 minutes when we did three sold out reunion shows in 2006. We made a blip on the national scene when we were signed to C/Z Records back in 1991 and released in 1993 the Vena Cava recording, produced and engineered by Jack Endino. The C/Z connection opened up doors for many successful national tours with Sunny Day Real Estate, Alcohol Funnycar, Monks Of Doom, and of course, Treepeople. We formed in 1988 and released two recordings: our self-released "Demo Tape" and Glenn's Car on the Silence Records label, produced and engineered by Drew Canulette (Soundgarden/Nirvana/Dharma Bums). An appearance at Treefort 2018 would be an honor for us to celebrate our 30th reunion.

body.name: the Raven and the Writing Desk

song.artist_name: the Raven and the Writing Desk
song.title: Stay the Same

body.bio: Seasonal moulting. We need it - catharsis, change - we try to unstick ourselves to any one moment in time. This band has been many different bands. Who we are now might be completely different from who we will be tomorrow. In the past few years we set an emphasis on co-creation. We found ourselves in the woods writing music from morning to night - nothing but music. No rules - no preconceived ideas. We wanted to go about things with a little more purity in mind. You’ll hear many of these songs as we hit the road again this Spring. We are on to something - gonna follow it to the next scene.

body.name: Ben Stein
body.bio: Benjamin Stein joined Andrade Legal as an associate attorney in January of 2013 to work on the firm’s deportation defense, naturalization, family-based immigration, and asylum docket. Prior to joining Andrade Legal, Benjamin worked and volunteered in different areas of immigration law, and gained invaluable experience working on the United States-Mexico border as a law clerk at Casa de Proyecto Libertad, a non-profit in Harlingen, Texas. Since joining Andrade Legal, Benjamin has consistently represented clients in both detained and non-detained removal defense cases, and has traveled to family detention centers at the United States-Mexico border to represent detained mothers and children fleeing violence. Benjamin has also argued federal court cases before the District Court of Idaho and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, and has been asked to speak at national conferences on recent legal issues.

body.name: Red Hands Black Feet

song.title: I Leave You and the Earth Behind

body.bio: Red Hands Black Feet has been best described as, "...dreamy post-rock with a helpful [dose] of sludge, sending furious blast-beats to chase down the starry gaze of delayed guitars and solemn melodies." (Eden Kupermintz, Heavy Blog is Heavy). Combining the twinkling guitars of Explosions in the Sky with the sonic pressure of The Melvins, Red Hands Black Feet composes instrumental concept albums much like soundtracks with no film. They have released two full length albums, These Things Are Important and We Must Fall Forever If We Survive, and are returning to the studio in the spring of 2018 to record their third.

body.name: Oddisee & Good Compny
body.bio:
The son of Sudanese and American parents, Amir Mohamed was born and raised in the United States capital city of Washington DC, spending hot summers in Khartoum learning Arabic and swimming in the Nile. Growing up amidst the sounds of New York hip hop, his father playing Oud, Go-Go, and gospel, Amir took his first steps as an MC producer in the analog basement studio of his legendary neighbor, Garry Shider (Parliament Funkadelic).

 Convincing his entrepreneurial father that he too had business acumen, Amir laid the check from his first commercial release on the kitchen table before his 21st birthday and never looked back. Though Oddisee has gone on to perform with The Roots, produce for Jazzy Jeff, Little Brother, & De La Soul, form the critically acclaimed group Diamond District with fellow Washingtonians X.O. and yU, and become a world renown musician.  

 His work has been featured on the Facebook Series Humans of New York, in countless films, television ads for everything from snowboards to bicycles, and even at Google's product unveiling.  In 2017 he preformed at over 110 shows around the globe with his band Good Compny in support of his album "The Iceberg."  He has been featured almost everywhere from Time Magazine and USA Today to Pitchfork and Rolling Stone.

Known in the music industry for his independence, Oddisee consistently debunks the scatterbrained artist myth - doing everything from booking international tours to photography to marketing and promoting himself and even other artists. He has been signed with Mello Music Group since 2008.

body.name: Christopher Sundberg
body.bio: Chris Sundberg, a local to Boise, and comedian for upwards of three years now, identifies himself as having a surrealist/absurdist bent. He has performed in Idaho Laugh Fest, competed in The World Series of Comedy, and is not uncommonly brought on stage to some variation on the phrase "Every local comic's favorite comedian."

body.name: Heatwarmer
body.bio: Heatwarmer is a three-piece band (keyboards, guitars and drums) that is a little less weird than Weird Al, but not by much. Most of their songs sound like they're joking around, which they basically are. However, the music is very  carefully composed and it sounds like a combination of The Doobie Brothers, Herbie Hancock and the soundtrack to E.T. It wouldn't be out of place playing in the background at a K-Mart in 1990. Most people call it "yacht rock" but none of the members have been on a yacht.

body.name: The Trees The Trees
body.bio:
We are The Trees The Trees, a local Bluesy Folk band with saucy fiddle solos, tight guitar fills, moody, driven piano rhythms,  and harmonies that would make the angels weep. We have been performing at local Boise venues for the last 5 months. Our members consist of;

Cam - (Lead vocals, harmonies, lead and rhythm guitar, writer) A Boise Native that has been involved in music since he was 5 years old. A U of I grad that has had a slew of jobs ranging from wildland fire fighter to Radio DJ to English Teacher in China to Pro and residential A/V work. Summers spent traveling, floating the riv and winters spent skiing and hunting down hot springs. 

Scott Sweet - (Vocals, harmonies, lead and rhythm guitar, writer) Scot has been playing in local bands for a few years now and has finally settled in with a project he loves. From Portland Oregon he grew up in a close proximity to amazing local music and has let his experiences shape the way he plays.

Hardcore Danny (fiddle extraordinaire) Anything for the music. Danny has had the need to play and to be heard his whole life. A fun loving charismatic guy who can shred like the greats on stage.

Zach (Piano) A man shrouded in mystery. No one knows where he came from or where he is going but he found his way into The Trees The Trees and it looks like he is here to stay

We have been working so hard to get to where we are now and the train just keeps on rolling.

-TtTt

body.name: Cindy Wilson
body.bio:
Cindy Wilson’s current endeavor is as far from The B-52s as one can possibly imagine. Rather than shouting from the rooftops in "The World’s Greatest Party Band", Wilson swoons and whispers over swirls of subtle psychedelia, Quincy Jones-era strings, and pulsing synths.

With echoes of Air, Bjork, Tame Impala, and Gary Numan, the band refers to its infectious brand of new wave electro-pop as "Turbo Chill,” a sonic synopsis offered by the hosts of Adult Swim’s Stupid Morning Bullshit following the release of Wilson’s solo debut EP, Sunrise. Three years in the making, Change offers a challenge to fans of the iconic B-52’s, while cultivating a new generation of listeners.

After four decades on the road internationally with The B-52s, Change represents a full circle for Wilson. Tapping into her own local stock in order to start anew, Cindy returned to the same town that nurtured her own creative roots: Athens, Georgia. Change features a “native” cast of Athenian musicians including Ryan Monahan (Easter Island, Monahan), producer/engineer Suny Lyons (PacificUV, Dream Boat), Lemuel Hayes (Ola Moon, PacificUV), and Marie Davon (powerkompany).

“It’s very different from a B-52’s show,” Wilson recently told PopMatters. “I get to play around with different ideas and beautiful melodies. I don’t have to yell in a rock voice. I think you can get an emotional depth in the types of rooms we’re playing that you can’t find in larger rooms.”

The album Change was released on December 1st on Kill Rock Stars, and the band is currently touring the U.S. and Europe to promote the release.

body.name: Simber
body.bio:
The alias of Gus Marsden (previously of Boise local alt-rock group Phonetic and electronic solo project Comfy but Conflicted), Simber is a abstract electronic music project in its infancy. 

While Simber as a concept has been in the works for quite a while, the project was officially launched in the fall of 2017 with a series of multi-media releases online. 

Simber blends atmospheric electronic with more experimental, abstract aspects creating a unique sound.

body.name: Jetski
body.bio: The brothers Jetski were born of discontent. Wading around in the blue collar routine of paperwork, phone calls, and cold sandwiches, the roar for something more came to rise. Brenton (bass) put on his sweat pants, Bobbie (drums) bought a baseball bat, and Marco (guitar) turned up the volume. Cubicles collapsed, neckties unraveled, brief cases burned and fuzz pedals engaged.  With the smell of the 90's in the air, Jetski created their first record "2PM" in 2017.

body.name: Olivia Cathcart
body.bio: Olivia Cathcart is an Atlanta-based stand-up comedian. Her comedy has often been described as smart and clever by many, and once was told, “I thought you’d be terrible, but that shit was funny” by one guy who doesn’t know how to give a compliment. He’s dead now (cholesterol). She has performed at the 208 Comedy Fest (Boise), Crom Comedy Festival (Omaha), Orlando Indie Comedy Fest, Hell Yes Fest (New Orleans), Red Clay (Atlanta), Derby City (Louisville), and the Memphis Comedy Festival. She also bats a respectable .345 in wiffleball.

body.name: WEEED
body.bio:
WEEED features a quartet of best friends jammin’ on double drum sets, electric bass, guitar, flute, vocal harmony and ambient live looping. Their blend of heavy psychedelic wildness, trance and improvisation draws influence from musical traditions around the world as well as the sensuous landscape they call home in the Pacific Northwest.

Since 2009, they have produced a number of albums, extensively toured the US and shared the stage with bands such asAcid Mothers Temple, Wand and Dead Meadow and have often been compared with King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard, Fuzz and Pink Floyd.

body.name: The Regrettes
body.bio:
Perfectly imperfect - that’s one way to describe LA based punk act, The Regrettes. Writing songs that proudly bear a brazen and unabashed attitude in the vein of acts Courtney Barnett or Karen O - with a pop aesthetic reminiscent of 50’s and 60’s acts a la the Temptations or Buddy Holly - the LA based four piece create infectious, punk driven tracks.

Lead by outspoken frontwoman, Lydia Night, and comprised of Genessa Gariano on guitar, Sage Chavis on bass and drummer Maxx Morando, the group have left the LA rock scene floored, managing to capture the hearts of jaded rock critics while opening for acts like Kate Nash, Jack Off Jill, Bleached, Pins, Deep Vally and more. With nothing but demos available online, the group are already beginning to generate hype, from outlets like NPR, and with NYLON already heralding them them as a “punk act you should be listening to”.

From the opening moments on a track by The Regrettes, we’re greeted with a wall of guitars, infectious melodies and a wistful nostalgia that continues right until the final notes. Taking cues from acts like Hinds and Hole, there’s a wistful sense of youth and vulnerability that lies at the heart of each song.

A song by The Regrettes is, essentially, a diary entry into Lydia’s life. “My music is a spectrum of every emotion that I have felt in the last year, and you can hear that when you hear the songs. Everything that is happening in my life influences me. It’s everything from boys, to friends, to being pissed off at people, to being really sad. Just everything.”

The most intoxicating draw of The Regrettes is their bashful, heart-on-your-sleeve temperament - writing urgent and fast-paced pop songs with a punk rock mentality. “The way that we write, it’s all based on honesty,” muses Lydia on the group’s punk aesthetic. “If I finish a song, I’ll just leave it - I won’t really go back to it. I like things to feel in the moment and I don’t want it to be perfect. If I work on something too much I lose it and get bored and I want to do the next one..”

Lydia’s not afraid to have her feelings on display. “I am not scared of anyone judging me, I don’t care. I don’t give a fuck if someone doesn’t like what I have to say. For every person that likes you, there’s a person that doesn’t like you. No matter what, if people can relate to the music then it’s worth it. That’s what is cool for me.” And at the end of the day, isn’t that what punk music is all about?

body.name: Lola Marsh
body.bio:
Lola Marsh is a fresh indie-Pop band whose music combines on-the-sleeve-lyrics and deep warm harmonies.
They first made waves after a much-discussed performance at Primavera Sound in 2014, influential L.A. radio station KCRW called “incredible,” adding that Yael was “clearly meant for the stage". The band gained immediate industry attraction and they quickly joined forces with United Talent Agency (USA & Europe), Universal Music (Europe) and Sony ATV.
“Sirens,” their first single, debuted in March 2015; it quickly received a million streams  and reached #5 on Spotify’s list of the Top 10 Most Viral Tracks in U.S.
Their second single, “You’re Mine”, garnered 8 millions plays on Spotify and landed in the service’s top 3 Most Viral Tracks as well as in the top 3 of Hype Machine’s Most Popular Tracks ranking.

In January 2016 their awaited debut EP was released via Anova Music under exclusive license to Barclay records (Universal France). Later that year, they teamed up with Madsonik and wrote "Drift and Fall Again" the main theme from Criminal's original motion picture soundtrack.
It wasn't long till the band dominated stages at big-named European festivals including Primavera Sound, Pohoda, Exit, Dockville, Pukkelpop, Montreaux, FNAC & intensively toured Europe.
Following their breakthrough success, their debut album ‘Remember Roses‘ was released in June 2017. The leading single ‘Wishing Girl’ became a Spotify favorite, charted the top 40 German radio chart and was featured in an Ebay commercial.

body.name: Epsilon Games
body.bio:
Sabrina Jacques and Jade Létrouneau will be joining us from Montreal to host a workshop on narrative puzzle building for game levels. 

Sabrina always loved stories and spent the last 10 years searching for new ways to weave them into games. She directed cinematics and created narrative content for Assasin’s Creed, Eagle Flight and many other Ubisoft franchises. She recently co-founded Epsilon Games, a Montreal-based indie studio with a gender parity policy.  She's the Realisation and Narrative Director role for Destination Primus Vita, the new episodic game developed by this promising new studio. 
Jade is a designer in her core. She moved from graphic to game design in the hope of satisfying her life-long love of videogames. Her passion is so contagious, she was hired by Epsilon to be the architect of fun in Destination Primus Vita the moment she got out of school!

body.class_summary: A breakdown of basic choreography and hip hop's most iconic grooves, this movement experience will have you leaving with an arsenal of dance moves. We'll take time connecting to our bodies by slowly working through footwork, isolations, and choreography. This class is not only a great workout, but also an invigorating challenge for your brain as you connect the dance sequence together.
body.name: Corevette Dance
body.bio:
A collective power of ambitious females with intentions of reviving the human spirit through the ever lasting energy dance presents the body.

Workshop:
Saturday, 1-2PM
Groove Down Party
Music By ENOMILY
A breakdown of funky grooves to throwback songs, this movement experience will have you leaving with an arsenal of dance moves. We'll take time connecting to our bodies by slowly working through footwork and isolations. Dance is for everyone and we're here to bring the party!

body.name: Alec Lytle & Them Rounders
body.bio:
Having spent much of his life in a supporting role as a harmony singer and upright bass player, Alec Lytle began his solo music career at the urging of fellow musicians who convinced him that his personal songs deserved to be heard by a wider audience. Since then, he has played his nuanced acoustic music in clubs from Los Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, New York, Anchorage, and Seattle, to cafés in Thailand, music venues in Brazil and on any field or mountaintop where he can tell his stories to a few empathetic listeners, or simply the wide open spaces... often with just his intimate voice, heartbreaking words, and the sound of his little Martin acoustic guitar.

Lytle also performs his music live with an ever-changing group of musicians known as Alec Lytle & Them Rounders featuring upright bass, mandolin, pedal steel guitar, percussion, and harmony vocals. Now, with his debut album The End of Ours and a new EP to be released in 2018, his aim is to take listeners for an experience that can remind them of a simpler and calmer time. Americana influenced music that he strives to fill with a sense of place... the tall pines, rolling hills, and blankets of enveloping coastal fog that define his home, the rural coastal mountains of Northern California.

Lytle wrote most of the songs for The End of Ours over the four years he lived in a yurt he built in the Santa Cruz Mountains. Most nights were spent alone with the Pacific coastal fog collecting in the redwood trees overhead, dripping onto the canvas roof... Lytle often says that the solitude of living in the tent structure forced him to think about, and to ultimately write songs dealing with some painful events in his own life. In ‘The End of Ours’ the songwriter compiles a series of songs that document loss, from the end of relationships to the deaths of loved ones.

body.name: Treasure Valley Product Managers Workshop
body.bio: Experience Designer Summit - The Summit is intended for industry professionals who need to offer a better and different experience for customers, suppliers, and partners , which is more sustainable and profitable compared to other organizations competing on price, sales campaigns, programs, promotions or features.

body.name: Ponderay
body.bio:
Ponderay started when Brian Anglin and Jared Goodpaster got together to write songs and play around with guitar pedals. Shortly after, Brion Rushton and Nick Archibald jumped on board with bass and drums cutting a swath of jazzy punk and spacey folk tunes. 
"Breezy and freaky." -Kelsey Swope
"It sounds like a sunset." -Erin Cunningham

body.name: Lauren Ober
body.bio:
Lauren Ober is the host of WAMU’s The Big Listen, the “broadcast about podcasts.” Before taking the helm of this program, she was an award-winning radio producer for WAMU’s weekly newsmagazine, Metro Connection. Ober’s stories have been heard on other public radio shows, including NPR’s All Things Considered, Morning Edition and Here & Now, PRI’s The World and Latino USA, as well as podcasts like Criminal, 99% Invisible, Gravy and KCRW’s Unfictional. Ober previously served as producer of Orbital Path, a podcast from PRX about the cosmos and our place in it.

In 2015, Ober was a recipient of the French American Foundation Immigration Journalism Fellowship and traveled to Russia to report on LGBT immigration. Currently, Ober is a board member of the Association of Independents in Radio (AIR). She is a graduate of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University, American University and the Transom Story Workshop. A proud Pittsburgh native, she has a deep and abiding love for pierogi.

Give The Big Listen host a look-see! https://www.wnycstudios.org/story/myth-all-great-podcast-ideas-are-taken/

Give The Big Listen a listen! https://biglisten.org/

body.name: The Green Zoo
body.bio: The Green Zoo is a loose collective of musicians that has developed their very own brand of spacey pop.  We shift from lush, distorted soundscapes, to sparse spacey melodies to tripped-out grooves from song to song.  You bring your ears, we'll sex up the sax and hand out the psychedelics.

body.name: The Sun and the Mirror

song.title: The Ashes of Our Loved Ones

body.bio: The Sun and The Mirror is a mixed genre experimental project, grounded in heavy psych, darkwave, noise, dark ambient, and drone, with elements of folk, dark orchestral, and doom, all used to create soundscapes for the audience to exist within.  They create an atmosphere at once intimate and enveloping. They are some sort of marriage between AHNOHNI and Earth.

body.name: Fruit & Flowers
body.bio:
Fruit & Flowers are one of the most active bands in the NYC area, and have been deemed one of "NYC's Hardest Working Bands" by Oh My Rockness. Fruit & Flowers' exuberant, electric performances draw a local following. Ana Becker's angular, expressive guitar style and Lyzi Wakefield's gritty rhythmic backbone merge a post-punk heaviness with psychedelic warmth. Committed and charismatic front woman Caroline Yoder summons a fervent energy, surrounded by distinct, warm and refreshing three part harmonies, the bedrock of Fruit and Flowers' sound.

Conceived in a Bushwick loft with broken AC during the summer of 2015 by Caroline on bass and Shaw Walters on drums, the band was soon joined by Lyzi Wakefield and Ana Becker on guitars and vocals.
