'I Need to Start a Garden' is relatable in how it speaks to the odious realities we attempt to confront daily, accompanied by a heavy dose of self-reflection. Heynderickx knows your pain -- she speaks to it in no uncertain terms through her personal expositions, entwining her healing process with yours.

The album was produced and mixed by Zak Kimball at Nomah Studios in Portland. It features Lily Breshears (Shears) on keys and backing vocals; Denzel Mendoza on trombone; Phillip Rogers (Alexandra Savior) on drums; and Tim Sweeney on upright bass. I Need to Start a Garden will be released March 2nd, 2018 by Mama Bird Recording Co.

body.name: Hokum Hi-Flyers
body.bio: Based in Boise, Idaho, the Hokum Hi-Flyers play old-time mountain music and other forms of unplugged American roots music on fiddle, banjo, guitar, mandolin, bass, and harmonica. Part of the living tradition of "old, weird America," they sing songs of love and murder, sin and redemption, whiskey and whimsy. High-spirited dance tunes will get you on your feet and hollerin' at the rafters. Come chase away the blues at their regular square dances at the Mardi Gras Ballroom in downtown Boise. They serve up hokum and they serve it hot.

body.name: Host
body.bio:
Host is the recording and performance project from the Providence, Rhode Island artist Alex Maddalena. 

Building on the elemental loop work of his first LP, his new album, Time Smoking A Picture, reinterprets classical structures for the electric guitar. The result is a two part work that’s as cinematic and operatic as it is emotionally devastating. The same crescendos and guttural walls of sound that christened the genre “Desk Metal” for his early works are present here along with a newfound sonic and emotional depth.

body.name: Stormshadow
body.bio: StormShadow has been a long time Boise favorite for nearly 20 years.  A fellow partner & promoter of Esthetic Evolution, and former resident of Crowbar in Boise, Stormshadow keeps the vibe high and maintains a positive energy on the dance floor.  Spinning tunes with grooving, bass- heavy undertones with a psychedelic feel, from trance to techno, Stormshadow is sure to expand your mind, heart and soul.

body.name: Breakthrough: How To Get Noticed
body.bio: Often times bands send out dozens of emails looking for industry support, but how do they break through the noise? A mix of music industry vets spanning record labels, PR professionals, media publications, sync licensing agents and talent buyers come together to share their experiences working with artists who have been able to break through and get noticed. Panelists will share real stories of how they discovered certain acts and what set them apart in the discovery process. We'll cover the do's and don't of submitting music for consideration. There is an outlet for everybody, it's just a matter of finding it.

body.name: Bianca Cristovao
body.bio: Bianca Cristovao is an international stand up comic. She was last year Laugh Factory's Funniest Person in the World finalist as well as this year HBO Comedy Wings finalist and appeared on Czech Late Night television show. When she doesn't perform stand up comedy she writes and directs (WhoHaha, channel 101) She also hosts a podcast (Mixed Up with Bianca and Madison) and produces her monthly comedy show the Iron Curtain. She's been recently seen at the Second City Comedy festival, Baron Vaughn's residency at the Hollywood Improv and LA's legendary showcase Hot Tub with Kurt and Kirsten.

body.name: Dear Rabbit
body.bio:
Even with three LPs under his belt, front man Rence still considers himself new on the scene. Dear Rabbit's latest release, They're Not Like You, is the first one to receive the acclaim that truly excites Rence, drawing comparisons to a New York sound and indy rawk beyond -- Lou Reed, Jonathan Richman, Silver Jews, Daniel Johnston, etc.

Recently joined with a full band, Dear Rabbit has shared six years of heartfelt performances of their songs across various stages, sweaty basements, intimate living rooms, warehouse spaces, beer soaked dive bars and beyond, throughout 48 states and six Canadian provinces to date.With great excitement, Rence and Dear Rabbit present to you their latest cast for Treefort 2018!

body.name: William Ritter
body.bio:
Reports of William Ritter’s birthplace are unreliable and varied, placing his hometown either in a series of mysterious Catacombs in Malta or in a quiet town in Oregon. His parents, it can be confirmed, raised him to value intelligence, creativity, and individuality. When reading aloud, they always did the voices.

At the University of Oregon, William made questionable choices, including willfully selecting classes for the interesting stories they promised, rather than for any practical application. When he wasn’t frivolously playing with words, he earned credits in such meaningful courses as Trampoline, Juggling, and Seventeenth Century Italian Longsword. These dubious decisions notwithstanding, he regrets nothing and now holds degrees in English and education with certificates in creative writing and folklore.

He currently teaches high school language arts, including reading and writing, mythology and heroes. He is a proud husband and father. When reading aloud, he always does the voices.

Jackaby is his first novel. It was born in the middle of the night and written on two different hemispheres. It has survived typhoons and hurricanes and was fostered into publication through the patient care of many hands. Beastly Bones is his second novel.

body.name: Fortcraft
body.bio:
Fortcraft is back! Fortcraft is an open interactive building experience for kids and parents and anyone in between. Like a real world Minecraft you can use cardboard, tape, markers and chalk to build the fort of your dreams, add on to other forts, decorate existing structures or make something else entirely. Throughout the event, structures will be made, taken down and remade again into something new. 

Under the direction of Travis Olson and awesome Treefort volunteers, challenges will be suggested. Kids can choose to participate in them or ignore them completely. There is no wrong way to Fortcraft.

body.name: Sun Valley Gun Club
body.bio:
Sun Valley Gun Club is a Northern California band that has arguably listened to way too much Pavement. Known for “endearingly loose” guitar-rock (San Jose Metro) and wall-of-sound live shows, their second studio album finds the band expanding their references. The eponymous LP draws on decades of rock-and-roll as broad ranging as guitar tones lifted from 1960's psychedelia and folk rock; the concept albums of 1970’s art rock and an up-front, sometimes aggressive vocal delivery reminiscent of early 2000’s indie rock.

Sun Valley Gun Club, LP, has been hailed as “nuanced and innovative” (SF Deli), and “shifting and complex” (Sacramento News and Review). Lyrically the songs are narratives inspired by film, classic Science Fiction, and the Bible, without being "buried in symbolism. It sounds like a person making sense of life." (Submerge) It is a record about cultural and religious fixation on the apocalypse, self-fulfilling prophecy, Will Smith, and the imperative of people to forgive, if not their loved ones, then at least themselves.

body.name: PremRock & Fresh Kils
body.bio: Thousands of words have been spilled on the technical prowess of Toronto producer Fresh Kils and his assault on the MPC, while New York emcee PremRock has written thousands more crisscrossing the globe studying Tom Waits and Ernest Hemingway. The duo has united through pen and the pads and performed in over a dozen countries and 50+ cities together. The critically lauded "Leave In Tact" has been become their quintessential effort as a fresh spin on a classic sound.

body.name: Jeff Crosby
body.bio:
Born and raised in Idaho, Jeff Crosby has been sharing his unique perspective of Americana throughout the US and beyond for the past decade. His songs are a collection from growing up in a small town in Idaho with all of the hardships and beauty of living in small town America, to five years living in a shoebox apartment off Sunset Blvd in Los Angeles CA, then to traveling and living on the road playing 250 shows a year. Though recently making the move to Nashville TN, Jeff continues to spend majority of his time touring the country. 

After spending the last two years splitting his time between playing guitar for Widespread Panic song-writer Jerry Joseph and performing with his own band, Jeff hit the studio to produce his fourth full length album, Postcards from Magdalena. The collection of songs was inspired by the places and cultures Crosby experienced while traveling across the U.S., Iceland, the UK., Colombia, Nicaragua, and Alaska. 
Produced and engineered by Gregg Williams (Dandy Worhals, Blitzen Trapper, Pete Droge, Jesse Malin), Postcards from Magdalena is set to release October 27th, released by UK label At The Helm Records.

body.name: Field Medic
body.bio: field medic is lo-fi bedroom project of kevin patrick. field medic began recording songs to cassette in his house in 2013 & has released a handful of EPs & a full length album. drawing inspiration from joni mitchell, fionn regan, nick drake, & bob dylan, field medic makes freak folk/post country with emphasis on fingerstyle guitar & lyrics.

body.name: Jamila Woods
body.bio:
Jamila Woods’ cultural lineage–from her love of Lucille Clifton’s poetry to cherished letters from her grandmother to the infectious late 80s post punk of The Cure–structure the progressive, delicate and minimalist soul of HEAVN, her debut solo album. “It’s like a collage process,” she says. “It’s very enjoyable to me to take something I love and mold it into something new.” A frequent guest vocalist in the hip-hop, jazz and soul world, Jamila has emerged as a once-in-a-generation voice on her soul stirring debut.

Born and raised on the Southside of Chicago, Woods grew up in a family of music lovers. It took a surprise poetry class with a high school arts program for Jamila to finally find her metaphorical and literal voice. “Through poetry, I realized you are the expert of your own experience,” she says. 

Her poetry studies continued in college and in her professional career with Young Chicago Authors. Music–like poetry– is personal. “It became a way to stop hiding, to actually be the most honest with myself through writing,” she says. “It helps me check in with myself.” And that honesty translated to HEAVN, an album she describes as a collection of, “nontraditional love songs pushing the idea of what makes a love song.” 

You’ll find the bits and pieces of her past and present that make Jamila: family, the city of Chicago, self-care, and the black women she calls friends.

Jamila is an artist of substance creating music crafted with a sturdy foundation of her passions and influences. True and pure in its construction and execution, her music is the best representation of Jamila herself: strong in her roots, confident in her ideas, and attuned to the people, places and things shaping her world.

body.name: Micki McElya
body.bio: Micki McElya is the Director of the Women’s, Gender & Sexuality Studies Program and Associate Professor of History at the University of Connecticut. She specializes in the histories of women, gender, racial formation, and sexuality in the United States from the Civil War to the present, with an emphasis on political culture and memory. Her recent book The Politics of Mourning: Death and Honor in Arlington National Cemetery (Harvard University Press, 2016) was named a Choice Outstanding Academic Title of 2017, winner of a John Brinckerhoff Jackson Book Prize from the Foundation for Landscape Studies and the inaugural Sharon Harris Book Award from the UConn Humanities Institute, and finalist for the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction and the 2016 Jefferson Davis Book Award from the American Civil War Museum. Along with several articles and book chapters, she is also author of Clinging to Mammy: The Faithful Slave in Twentieth-Century America (Harvard University Press, 2007). McElya received her B.A. in history from Bryn Mawr College in 1994 and a Ph.D. from New York University in 2003. Before joining the faculty of the University of Connecticut, she was an assistant professor of American Studies at the University of Alabama (2003-2008). She is currently at work on a book entitled Liberating Beauty: Feminism, the Civil Rights Movement, and Miss America.

body.name: ill-esha
body.bio: Vancouver-born and Colorado-based music producer, artist and DJ ill-esha has crafted a long-standing soundscape of bass music throughout her career, continuously evolving her musical stylings and bridging gaps between electronic, hip hop and soul.  Recognized as an extremely rare and diverse artist in the EDM scene, ill-esha is constantly pushing the boundaries of live sets with everything from loop pedals to keytars.  Constantly evolving her dynamic and versatile musical taste, she is a perfect example of electronic music’s transition towards live instrumentation and indie pop sensibility.

body.name: Five Alarm Funk
body.bio:
Vancouver, B.C., has always been a musical town. But back in The Day, as far as sizzling, soulful funk, it was something of a desert … until some mysterious force drew two young cats together who would change that in a hurry.

From their first house party jams, drummer Tayo Branston and guitarist Gabe Boothroyd gathered a community of musicians who shared their love for James Brown, Tower Of Power, Tito Puente, Antibalas, Frank Zappa and other adventurous groove-driven players. They called themselves Five Alarm Funk, drew more than 300 fans to their first gig at a local place called The Fairview Pub, established a residency at Richards On Richards where upwards of 800 attendees would show up each night -- and eventually embarked on a 37-day, cross-continental track involving 30 shows from Vancouver to Fredericton.

Since then they’ve expanded their territory to include the U.S., played as far afield as Taiwan, rocked the Riverbend Festival in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and begun releasing EPs and CDs. The most recent of these, 2017’s Sweat, explodes with fiery rhythms, punchy horns and gang-chant vocals that sum up the irresistible essence of this band.

They’re now deep into a new project that involves adding all-star guest vocals onto some of the more volatile tracks from their catalog, beginning with a Bootsy Collins appearance. “I’ve been a Bootsy Collins fan ever since I was 15,” Branston marvels. “That track we gave him, ‘Capital City,’ is one of the funkiest things we’ve ever cut. With that experience and our back catalog, you’ll see a lot more of this from us.”

Future releases and reissues with big-time rappers and funksters. Sights set on bringing their magic to festivals throughout the world. More sweat, more dancing … more Five Alarm Funk.

body.name: Kadeejah Streets
body.bio:
Ice.
Gold.
Acid.
Guitars.
Walking The Night.
Champagne.
Tartan Ponchos.
Penguins.

That sums some of it up.

body.class_summary:
Find your inner warrior and blow the doors off of your fears.  From this place of strength and personal power, we create and achieve our wildest dreams.  But what about the softer side?  The humble warrior teaches us to bow to the teacher within and to be guided by wisdom and intuition. It allows us to show up with gratitude.  The peaceful warrior shows us how to have compassion and honor for ourselves and others.  Being a yoga warrior does not mean being a fighter.  It means being YOU in the biggest sense of the word.  The movement and play will help you get out of your head and into your body, so you can more easily access your heart, which is where your personal truth and your inner warrior are found. Be ready to move and to laugh - because through our JOY we manifest all things - and to challenge your mind and body in new ways. 

This is an active all levels class.  Options are offered and students can always move at their own pace, guided by their own intuition.
body.name: Dena Stoltz
body.class_title: Inner Warrior Rock N Roll Vinyasa Flow
body.bio:
Dena’s 20 years of experience bring a dynamic, fun, and energetic play to her classes.  They combine elements of strength and surrender, or Sukha and Sthira.  Her classes are strong, yet fun and easily adaptable for all levels - from the beginner to the experienced yogi. Her silly sense of humor and personal life experience permeate every class.  Her practice has helped her to figure out who she is, and that is what she hopes it can do for others - by unlocking the doors and breaking down the walls of our inner world so that we may shine brighter and live bigger, fuller lives.

Workshop:
Sunday, 10-11AM
Music By Sol Rising
Find your inner warrior and blow the doors off of your fears. From this place of strength and personal power, we create and achieve our wildest dreams. But what about the softer side? The humble warrior teaches us to bow to the teacher within and to be guided by wisdom and intuition. It allows us to show up with gratitude. The peaceful warrior shows us how to have compassion and honor for ourselves and others. Being a yoga warrior does not mean being a fighter. It means being YOU in the biggest sense of the word. The movement and play will help you get out of your head and into your body, so you can more easily access your heart, which is where your personal truth and your inner warrior are found. Be ready to move and to laugh - because through our JOY we manifest all things - and to challenge your mind and body in new ways.

body.name: Black Belt Eagle Scout
body.bio:
MOTHER OF MY CHILDREN
“Having this identity—radical indigenous queer feminist—keeps me going. My music and my identity come from the same foundation of being a Native woman.” Katherine Paul is Black Belt Eagle Scout, and after releasing an EP in 2014 Paul has wrapped up the band’s first full-length. Recorded in the middle of winter near her hometown in Northwest Washington, the landscape’s eerie beauty and Paul’s connection to it are palpable on Mother of My Children. Stemming from this place, the album traces the full spectrum of confronting buried feelings and the loss of what life was supposed to look like. 

Growing up on a small Indian reservation, Paul’s family was focused on native drumming, singing, and arts. “Native American music is the foundation for all of my music,” Paul explains. With the support of her family and a handful of bootleg Hole and Nirvana VHS tapes, Paul taught herself how to play guitar. In 2007, Paul moved to Portland, OR, to attend school and get involved with the Rock ’n’ Roll Camp for Girls. Paul has switched between guitar and drums in an assortment of projects over the last decade, citing Forest Park as a particularly strong influence on how her songwriting has grown. “It was my introduction to post-rock,” Paul recalls, “From there, I was able to develop my own sound and style more.”

On Mother of My Children, Black Belt Eagle Scout tenderly blends post-rock with Paul’s earlier grunge influences and later, more confessional Pacific Northwest artists like Ô Paon and Mirah. The album begins with the singles “Soft Stud” and “Indians Never Die”, and on the latter, Paul’s message is clear: “It’s a call out to colonizers and those who don’t respect the Earth; they don’t care about the water, they don’t care about how they are destroying what is around them. Indigenous people are the protectors of this land, and others need to wake up and get on the same page.” The songs weave together to capture both the enduring and fleeting experiences of loss, frustration, and dreaming. The structures are traditional, but the lyrics don’t adhere to any format other than what feels right in the moment. “I don’t play music to write songs,” Paul explains, “I play music to process feelings, and sometimes what comes out of that is a song.” Paired with Paul’s clear and measured voice, each song leaves the listener feeling as if they were there when the song was written, the immediate, candid emotion tangible.

Mother of My Children is a life chapter gently preserved, and the access listeners have to such vulnerability feels special and generous. We are left wanting more, and all signs point to Black Belt Eagle Scout just getting started. The album is out on Good Cheer Records in August 2017.

—Alex Hebler

body.name: Kathleen Williams
body.bio: Singer Songwriter who wants to be your friend

body.name: Quinn DeVeaux
body.bio: Quinn DeVeaux and the Blue Beat Review is a dance and groove band with hopping mad rhymes and rhythms. Quinn has been playing soul and blues in the bay area for years and has finally started his own band The Blue Beat Review! It's sweet melody and soul music with a groove that makes you wanna use your feet for moving. This band is at the root of it and keeps the people in a state of joy.

body.name: Eleanor Murray
body.bio: Informed by folk tradition while adhering to no rules, Eleanor Murray’s music exists in a genre all its own. On her last outing, Bury Me Into the Mtn, she has created an album that is structurally complicated, while also sparse and open, full of warmth and light. Her chord progressions, rhythms and melodies draw as much from Appalachia as they do from jazz. Her lyrics are as cryptic as they are simple and straightforward. The album’s sonic landscape is completely its own.  Eleanor Murray has spent the last twelve years playing and recording music out of Olympia, WA. Her five albums have spanned a wide range of material and her side projects extend this range even further, currently with the electro-pop production of Cavegreen.

body.name: Jimmy Bowman
body.bio: Jimmy is extremely excited to be a part of Storyfort for the second year in a row. After acting and performing improv comedy in LA for 10 years, Jimmy is now back to living full time in Boise, Idaho where he writes and teaches, filling his free time with podcasts about things tangentially related to baseball. If you ever want Jimmy to do a favor for you, please lure him with vegan chocolate or tiny, snorty dogs like pugs or French bulldogs.

body.name: Leafraker
body.bio:
"listen seedpod, me 'n' ur Aunties useta look after this big ol cosmic entity what crashed in yonder forest ohhhhhh about fifty... maybe sixty cycles ago i reckon... busted right thru the canopy 'n' made a crater deep as u like... broke all but an augur's dozen of its roiling appendages on impact 'n' visited calamity on ur Aunty Thleen's aqueduct matrix ta boot... well as u can speculate i was none too mirthful over the damage 'n' loathe to start haulin ur Great Aunty Maphin's decoy urn ta splash drink on my brassicas 'n' topiaries again like distant unfond seasons of sweaty toil... 'n' ol Thleen was intent on straightforward violence as a matter of course... buuuuut as u ought t've guessed by now ur Aunty Brelfa gone 'n' done an astral confluence what coaxed the celestial behemoth's descent, 'n' so we was duty-bound ta aide in its laborious recuperation... now we gone 'n' dunked in some positively viscid baths of goo in our time, but it is my solemn testimony that this pertickler undertaking was beyond all doubt the most mucilaginous... we had ta excavate segments of the colossal body what became entangled in the woodsy roots 'n' earthen hollows... ol Thleen had ta crawl inside the cavernous nasal resonating tubes 'n' flush out an errant passel of trufflesnoots what mistook the tubes fer shelter... ol Brelfa had ta hexbind the abysmal mouths shut while i ministered sutures 'n' spumy unguents upon the—oh heaven's neck, it's after Nightscrest... wellllll anyhow, so as not to belabor the point, me 'n' ur Aunties inadvertently wrought blight 'n' desolation on yonder forest what we only been capable of undoin since just prior to the dawning of ur natal star, so the answer is no! g'night lil nannerpeel!"
— unembellished review of a typical Leafraker performance, as recounted by Aunty Pexebel to their apprentice, Yaxynel, well past bedtime

Leafraker is a non-binary starspawn whose body & essence are rapidly degenerating & being replaced w/ a sentient colony of human tears. They are irresponsibly mid-neck-deep in some pretty dark arts. They do some rap songs too, however, they are preparing to pupate again. Uhh, wtf is *that* supposed to mean? & what does all this Aunty nonsense even have to do w/ anything? Well why don't u ffffffrickin ask me again later during Treefort 20XX u thirstful cone?!

body.name: St. Terrible (and the Gospel of Nothingness ∆)

song.artist_name: St. Terrible (and the Gospel of Nothingness ∆)
song.title: Cosmic Nothings

body.bio: Come step into the immersive world of the Gospel of Nothingness, led by our Terrible Saint and filled with an eclectic range of lightning-mouthed music, ghostly theatrics, and more than a few moments of existential crises. Join in the joyful and noisy worship of nameless things.

body.name: Hanni El Khatib
body.bio:
On his 2011 debut 'Will The Guns Come Out,' Hanni El Khatib tried something he'd never tried before -- making a bedroom-style recording of his then stripped-to-the-skeleton guitar-and-drums rock 'n' roll mostly for the sheer joy of making it. For his ferocious 2013 follow-up 'Head In The Dirt,' he tried something new again, showing up at producer Dan Auerbach's analog-dreamland Nashville studio with nothing but the clothes on his back and an open mind.

But after 'Head In The Dirt''s release and almost a year of relentless touring, Hanni knew he needed to go past 'unpredictable' all the way to 'unprecedented.' He needed isolation, time and the chance to experiment. So after 30 days locked in hand-picked L.A. studio The Lair, the result is the album 'Moonlight' -- the rarest and most welcome kind of album, made at that perfect point in life where confidence, experience, and technique unite to help an artist do anything they want.

That's why it starts with a song that sounds like a Mobb Deep beat under a Suicide-style synth drone and ends with an ESG-meets-LCD Soundsystem gone italo-disco song about life and death. That's why it collides crushing crate-digger drumbeats that'd be right at home on a Can LP or an Eddie Bo 45 with bleeding distorto guitar, bent and broken barroom piano and hallucinatory analog flourishes. (In fact, some smart producer is going to sample the drums from this album and complete the circle of life.) And that's also why 'Moonlight' feels like the album he's always wanted to make: "What would it sound like if RZA got in the studio with Iggy Pop and Tom Waits?" he asks. "I don't know! That was my approach on everything."

It's a personal album in the most primal sense, put together in any way that worked. Iggy Pop and David Bowie did this kind of thing on 'The Idiot,' the Wu-Tang Clan did it on '36 Chambers' and the Clash did it three times over on 'Sandinista.' And now it's Hanni's turn, across 11 new lightning-struck songs, each written and recorded in its own flash of inspiration. It sounds like an album made by an endless list of collaborators, but really 'Moonlight' was more like the first do-it-almost-all-yourself music Hanni ever made, except after six years recording and touring, he'd learned to do so much more.

body.name: Overlake
body.bio:
Overlake is a three-piece band hailing from Jersey City, comprised of Tom Barrett (vocals/guitar), Lysa Opfer (Bass/vocals), and Nick D'Amore (drums).

Honing their own unique brand of melodic, guitar-driven dreampop since 2012, and drawing from such stalwart influences as My Bloody Valentine and Dinosaur Jr, their sound can only be described as massive and melodic. Barrett's delay-drenched guitar and whispery vocals, backed by the coupling of Opfer's driving basslines and D'Amore's solid beatkeeping, was once described as "a fluffy jackhammer penetrating the listener's eardrum."

Their latest critically-acclaimed record, Fall, came out on Bar/None Records in May 2017, and Overlake has shared stages with such notable artists as Mike Watt, Swervedriver, and The Brian Jonestown Massacre among others.

body.name: Culture Junkies: Live Podcast
body.bio: Hackfort Live! Yea, that's a thing and this year at Hackfort 2018, your favorite community radio station, Radio Boise and Culture Junkies, a new podcast lovingly dedicated to Boise's culture scene, will broadcast live on stage. This live podcast will feature interviews of key Hackfort's speakers and guests.

body.name: La Louma
body.bio:
For Lauren Ross, it took multiple breakdowns, lots of physical therapy, anti-depressants, and a move across the country before the clouds began to part, the music began to come, and La Louma emerged. On her debut, Let The World Be Flooded Out, she explores heavy subject matter in an upbeat atmosphere, merging her classical training with her DIY queer punk ethos.

Meticulously handcrafted over hundreds of hours of solitude, La Louma’s palette includes thickly melodic woodwinds and brass, electric guitar and bass, impatient drums, tremolo vocal undercurrents, and metaphor-laden lyrics. The LP’s tone repeatedly shifts unexpectedly from dramatic desperation to quiet contemplation, from a determined sprint to utter immobilization. Musically mirroring La Louma’s vagabond mind, each of the album’s richly transportive scenes are colored by carefully chosen modalities, timbres, instrumentations, and arrangements.

The opening track “The Decline of Nations” crashes through as a fist-raising call to “stay until you try to make things right”. As La Louma’s voice wails and breaks into a pointed and beautiful howl, it feels as though she could be singing to government officials, movement leaders, or even herself. Falling drum sticks and a slinking clarinet introduce "Candy", a mythology-driven song in which she vows to protect a narcissist from drowning in their own reflection—no matter the cost—while the more straightforward storytelling of the subtly Middle Eastern tinged "Just Wanna Love You" culminates in symphonic catharsis. The album's sonic anchor, "Tin Roof Now", makes use of nearly every instrument in La Louma's studio as she pleads for the simple sound of a heavy rain to "drown out [her] senses" and "let the world be flooded out".

This album is a thematic whirlwind with a musical hurricane to match, but isn’t that what life often feels like?

body.name: Zola Jesus
body.bio:
For over a decade, Nika Roza Danilova has been recording music as Zola Jesus. She's been on Sacred Bones Records for most of that time, and Okovi marks her reunion with the label.

Fittingly, the 11 electronics-driven songs on Okovi share musical DNA with her early work on Sacred Bones. The music was written in pure catharsis, and as a result, the sonics are heavy, dark, and exploratory. In addition to the contributions of Danilova's longtime live bandmate Alex DeGroot, producer/musician WIFE, cellist/noise-maker Shannon Kennedy from Pedestrian Deposit, and percussionist Ted Byrnes all helped build Okovi's textural universe.

With Okovi, Zola Jesus has crafted a profound meditation on loss and reconciliation that stands tall alongside the major works of its genre. The album peaks of tragedy with great wisdom and clarity. Its songs plumb dark depths, but they reflect light as well.

ARTIST STATEMENT:

Last year, I moved back to the woods in Wisconsin where I was raised. I built a little house just steps away from where my dilapidated childhood tree fort is slowly recombining into earth. Okovi was fed by this return to roots and several very personal traumas.

While writing Okovi, I endured people very close to me trying to die, and others trying desperately not to. Meanwhile, I was fighting through a haze so thick I wasn't sure I'd find my way to the other side. Death, in all of its masks, has been encircling everyone I love, and with it the questions of legacy, worth, and will.

Okovi is a Slavic word for shackles. We're all shackled to something -- to life, to death, to bodies, to minds, to illness, to people, to birthright, to duty. Each of us born with a unique debt, and we have until we die to pay it back. Without this cost, what gives us the right to live? And moreover, what gives us the right to die? Are we really even free to choose?

This album is a deeply personal snapshot of loss, reconciliation, and a sympathy for the chains that keep us all grounded to the unforgiving laws of nature. To bring it to life, I decided to enlist the help of Alex DeGroot, who has been the only constant in my live band and helped mix the Stridulum EP back in 2010. It will be released on Sacred Bones, the closest group of people I'll ever have to blood-bound family.

body.name: Tommy Alexander
body.bio:
Over a short period of time, Tommy Alexander has emerged as a modern-day DIY trailblazing troubadour. 

"A phenomenal talent." - Micheal McDonald (Doobie Brothers) 

"Wicked Indie rock." - Brett Lanier (Barr Brothers)

“Filled with an introspective and strikingly truthful style of songwriting, his music can be downright mind-bending -- especially for those of us who have grown used to Pandora's corporate jukebox and the cultural clichés that run with it.”
- Huffington Post

Tommy has been fortunate to share the stage with acts such as; Mac Demarco, Michael McDonald, Big Thief, Willy Tea Taylor, Spirit Family Reunion, Aaron Lee Tasjan, People Under The Stairs, SUSTO, Rising Appalachia, Night Beds ,Twain & Jay Cobb Anderson.

body.name: Luca Lush
body.bio: Luca Lush grew up playing self-taught drums in scene bands until he went to college, where he discovered drums don't fit in dorm rooms. Undeterred, he put down the sticks and began programming beats on his computer. Flash forward to 2017, Luca Lush has made a name for himself in electronic music, having toured internationally throughout last year behind a slew of popular remixes, including official releases with Ultra, Monstercat, and Columbia. With frequent premieres on tastemaker blogs such as Run The Trap and Too Future, Luca also receives support from Dillon Francis, Flosstradamus, Big Gigantic, Gramatik and The Chainsmokers. Now focused on releasing a bushel of original singles and collaborations, be sure to watch for Luca Lush coming to a venue or festival near you this year.

body.name: Marshall Simmonds, Define Media Group
body.bio: As a leader in the search industry since 1997, Marshall has consulted with the biggest brands online including; The New York Times, CNN, USAToday, Bloomberg, Salesforce, E Online, Business Insider, The Economist, The Street, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (KKR), Hearst Digital Publications, Time Inc, AOL, Conde Nast, Vimeo, Fodor’s, The Boston Globe (Boston.com), New York Magazine, About.com, Inc.,  Wenner Media, Newsweek, Oprah.com, AARP, TV Guide, ToysRUs, ESPN International, PCMag, NHL.com, National Geographic, Hewlett-Packard, CBS, The Canadian Broadcast Company, Gawker Media, and many others. Marshall Simmonds has access to, and crunches, massive internet data trends, stats and tools so you don’t have to. Simmonds will provide hacks, identify audience behavior and insight to ensure your content performs well on the internet.

body.name: Daniel Van Kirk
body.bio: SINCE MOVING TO LOS ANGELES, DANIEL HAS BECOME PART OF BOTH THE STAND-UP AND IMPROV/SKETCH COMMUNITIES, WORKING WITH THE UCB THEATRE, THE NERDIST CHANNEL, COLLEGE HUMOR, AND THE COMEDY PODCAST NETWORK, EARWOLF.COM AS WELL AS FERAL AUDIO. EVERY WEEK, DANIEL CAN BE HEARD CO-HOSTING THE PODCAST, "DUMB PEOPLE TOWN" WITH FELLOW COMEDIANS JASON AND RANDY SKLAR. DANIEL IS A FREQUENT GUEST ON THE PODCAST DOUG LOVES MOVIES, APPEARING AS “MARK WAHLBERG.” IN 2013, DANIEL WAS GIVEN HIS OWN SKETCH SHOW, "DVK," ON THE YOUTUBE COMEDY NETWORK, THE NERDIST CHANNEL.

body.name: Thank You For Your Stories: Veteran Narratives
body.bio: Five veterans with experience from Vietnam, the Balkan Crisis, and post-9/11 Iraq and Afghanistan will be telling their stories, and in moderated conversation about what their military lives mean to them now.

body.name: Another Man Out The Window
body.bio:
San Francisco based Another Man Out The Window is a musical force of berserk humans. AMOTW was formed in Rock Band Land, a music and storytelling school for young rockers in San Francisco, and over the last 6 years have evolved into their own entity which has reliably melted faces since its inception. 

AMOTW's writes riff based music that is both tweaky and fun, and reminiscent of bands like Minutemen and Butthole Surfers. They have released a full length album and an ep. In anticipation for this application AMOTW tracked a special live ep (see below) entitled Hella Old and they are  currently working on a new studio album.

body.name: Beth Norton
body.bio: Beth Norton got her start in stand-up in the Vermont comedy scene in 2014. She has since performed in showcases across the country and hosted for nationally touring headliners including Judah Friedlander! Her style has been described by fellow comedians as smart and understated. A natural story teller, her material comes from her childhood spent in foster care and what it is like to be a woman in America today.

body.name: Discoma
body.bio: Discoma is the electronic alter ego of Boise musician Jake Hite. His music layered and rhythmically complex.  Over the years Discoma has shared the stage with the likes of Tyondai Braxton, Author & Punisher, Wolf eyes, and Pinkish Black.

body.name: August McLaughlin
body.bio:
August McLaughlin is a health and sexuality writer and host and creator of Girl Boner®. Her work appears in Cosmopolitan, DAME Magazine, the Huffington Post, LIVESTRONG.com and more. Kirkus Reviews called her first novel, In Her Shadow, “an engaging story with an inventive structure and an intriguing focus on body-image issues.” Each week on Girl Boner® Radio, she interviews sex and relationship experts, celebrity entertainers, sex workers, entrepreneurs, survivors and more.

In 2016, she attended the United State of Women conference convened by the White House as a nominated change maker, spoke about surviving an eating disorder at a TEDx Women event in Beverly Hills (see the video here), and learned a heck of a lot about life, love and herself. Known for melding personal passion, artistry and activism, August uses her skills as a public speaker and journalist to encourage women to embrace their bodies and selves, making way for fuller, more authentic lives. Her first Girl Boner book will be released by Amberjack Publishing in 2018.

body.name: Nouveauxfaux
body.bio:
Our song ‘Gloria’ got a really swell review the other day that sums up what we’re chasing.

“This track is great in a "sounds like you feel when you're out dancing to Britpop and you're a little loopy and you make out with a girl and then she disappears and then you try to find her in the crowd and then you do and then you leave together and it's exciting" kind of way.”

We like big, driving bass. Heartquaking, motorik beats. And guitars that sound more like feelings and feel more like visions.

We’re a three-piece from Portland, Oregon, making psych-tinged avant-rock that derails as much as it delights.

body.name: IHC 1NFINITY: The First Record Label with a Shared Music Video Universe
body.bio: IHC 1NFINITY is the first record label with a shared music video universe. Created by IHEARTCOMIX, think of it as the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but without super heroes and happening with music videos, it’s one ongoing story told across artists. This unique take is designed to build an audience of it’s own alongside those of our artists creating an atmosphere where music and the experience is infinite. The program features music videos from Chela, Pictureplane, Gavin Turek, Mark Redito, starRo feat. Bosco, a preview of what’s to come next from Ho99o9 and a short documentary exploring the universe. The screening will be followed by a Q&A with creators Franki Chan and Jesus Rivera from IHEARTCOMIX.

body.name: máscaras
body.bio: Máscaras, comprised of three Portland music scene veterans is what happens when an off-the-cuff jam session between friends really, really works. Even in its recorded form, “it’s a jam with themes that live and breathe,” the band says, “leaving room for the unexpected.” The trio plays heavy, propellant psychedelic music with surf-rock twang and mathy sensibilities. They call it “maximalist indigenous psych”. These are urgent, intense songs, but they’re also playful. It’s the sound of three homies making exactly the music they want to make, for no one else but themselves. It just so happens that people love it.

body.name: Jennifer Tamayo
body.bio: Jennif(f)er Tamayo is a writer and performer. She received her Bachelor of Arts from the University of Chicago and her Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing from Louisiana State University. She is the author of the collection of poems and art work, Red Missed Aches Read Missed Aches Red Mistakes Read Mistakes (Switchback, 2011) and the limited edition chapbook POEMS ARE THE ONLY REAL BODIES  (Bloof Books, 2013).  Her second full collection of poems and artwork is YOU DA ONE (Noemi 2017, Coconut 2014). From 2010-2015, JT has served as the Managing Editor for Futurepoem an independent NYC press publishing contemporary poetry and prose. She is a Canto Mundo Fellow and a Hemispheric Institute for Performance and Politics EmergeNYC Fellow (2016.) She currently lives and works in Sacramento, California.

body.name: Gentle Spirit
body.bio:
Gentle Spirit is a musical project from San Francisco based artist Marcus Stoesz. The brooding and evocative self-titled LP from 2016 took form over 5 years as Stoesz was reportedly dealing with depression. The 20-minute ode to love “Dearest” was released in 2017 on hot-ticket tape label Gaylord’s Party Music. Currently a collaborative project with songwriters Sara Gallagher, Jeremie Rüest, Taylor Giffin and Gray Tolhurst, they are touring and performing songs from an as yet unannounced LP. The group’s performances are highlighted by its dreamy landscape of sound, Stoesz and Gallagher’s lush melodies and harmonies, and ever-so-slightly wobbly grooves. 

William Q. Funk

Praise for Gentle Spirit

One could be forgiven for thinking Stoesz had been recording music for decades, in terms of scope and depth, but the remarkable thing is how young he is; it's clear he's just getting started.
Do The Bay

Gentle Spirit has a calm reservation that is a signature of confidence and understanding of ones own sound. Reminds me of my first listen to Wilco. 
Hardly Davidson Music in Review

body.name: Camp Happy
body.bio: Bring your happy campers to experience the fun at Camp Happy! Happy Family's camp counselors will be hosting a variety of fun, learning-based activities! Get ready to run, reduce, reuse, and recycle in our recycling relay! Get crafting with veggie stamps on reusable organic cotton tote bags to take home! Get that green thumb started with planting seeds to bring back to your garden! For each activity you participate in you'll earn a camp stamp that you can then show at our Happy General Store to earn yummy, nutritious snacks! You can also expect some exciting musician pop-ups each day! And don't feel like you have to leave early - please take advantage of our private breast-feeding & diaper-changing tent!

body.name: Lala Lala
body.bio: Lala Lala is the grunge rock project of Lillie West. Based in Chicago the group has toured the US extensively over the last three years, supporting bands such as Cherry Glazerr, Girlpool and Together Pangea. Their debut record was released in 2016.

body.name: Tristan Andreas
body.bio: By day I develop advanced cleans for high density memory fabrication. By night I enjoy electronic music production and performance. I have over 40 patents in the area of semiconductor device manufacturing, and ~20 full length recordings with various musical projects.

body.name: Mike Coykendall
body.bio: Veteran songwriter, producer and multi-instrumentalist Mike Coykendall has been amazingly prolific over the last three decades or so. Currently most well known for his duties as a sideman, producer, and recordist via his work with M Ward, Blitzen Trapper, She & Him, Annalisa Tornfelt, & Tin Hat Trio, to name a few, Coykendall has been making his own unique outsider records since the mid '80s.

body.name: Robin Bacior
body.bio: Robin Bacior is a jazz pop musician based in Portland, Oregon. Her music has been featured by NPR's All Songs Considered, L Magazine, MTV, Vh1, and opbmusic. Her new record, Light It Moved Me, is out this spring.

body.name: Random Canyon Growlers
body.bio: Hard Drivin' Traditional Bluegrass and ripping old-time from Boise/Missoula !!!!!

body.name: SFM - Steve Fulton Music
body.bio:
Steve Fulton is a singer/songwriter from Boise, Idaho who performs under the stage name, SFM - Steve Fulton Music. He has performed all over the country for the last 20 years touring with his band and as a solo artist. His musical persona includes full band funky-rock-reggae and stripped down Americana.
In October 2016, SFM - Steve Fulton Music released "Eponym," the first new album in 11 years. Eponym finished the year as the number one selling CD at Idaho's largest independent record store, The Record Exchange in 2016.

body.name: A Long Strange Trip: Bands Tell All
body.bio: Treefort musicians will take the mic during happy hour, telling true, crazy, wonderful stories of the road as a touring musician. Cool prizes, including a Treefort 5-Day wristband, will be raffled off, too!

body.name: Wild Spells
body.bio:
Wild Spells (formerly We Are Apes) is an atmospheric witch pop band from Boise, Idaho. 

Wild Spells is an intersection of dream pop, doom, folk, and postrock. Formed in 2015, Wild Spells began as a duo called We Are Apes, with Erin Nelson, keyboardist and vocalist, and Eric Larson, guitarist and vocalist, in a single-room recording studio. In early 2016, the band expanded to four members, adding drummer Kory Parsley and bassist Zack Evans. In late 2017, the band changed their name to Wild Spells to better reflect the direction their music has taken as a four-piece ensemble, featuring shifts between quiet intensity and large, booming choruses. 

Wild Spells explores topics spanning the nature of femininity, our tense political atmosphere, religion, identity, intimacy, heartbreak, and much more. The band's first EP, titled Half-Dead Moon, debuts in May 2018.

body.name: Tears of Joy Theatre
body.bio:
THERE'S A NIGHTMARE IN MY CLOSET by Mercer Mayer

How do we overcome fear? What happens when we overcome that fear? This classic Tears of Joy production is performed with a variety of styles of puppets. Stories are tied together by the theme of facing and overcoming our fears in ways that will elicit both wonder and giggles. Performing three stories in one based on the theme of childhood fear and understanding the feelings of others.

The boy and the Nightmare are adaptations of Japanese bunraku puppets and the Jabberwocky is performed with three dimensional shadow puppets created from kitchen utensils which fuels the imagination!

body.name: Typhoon
body.bio:
The 14-track record Offerings is a musical and lyrical excursion into surreal imagery, eerie soundscapes, and an emotionally jarring narrative. 

The 70-minute album for Roll Call Records, which is the Portland, Oregon indie rock band's fourth studio album, centers on a fictional man who is losing his memory, and in turn, his sense of self. "I've always been preoccupied with memory, losing memory, and trying to recapture memory. I wanted to explore the questions: What does a person become if they don't know where they came from? What is the essential quality of the person if you strip away all memory?" explains singer/songwriter Kyle Morton.

Offerings is divided into four movements (Floodplains, Flood, Reckoning, and Afterparty) to represent the mental phases the main character goes through where he first realizes that something is wrong, then struggles through the chaos of his situation, and finally moves into acceptance before succumbing to his dreadful fate.

body.name: Timmy The Teeth
body.bio: Often described as a "Cowboy from the Crypt", Timmy The Teeth (aka Timothy George) has unknowingly found his way to the forefront of a new musical brand as genuine as his personality. After years behind the drum kit for frequent collaborators Joshua James and Desert Noises, Timmy The Teeth has now emerged as a unique voice at the forefront of the Utah music scene. Drawing from a tradition that spans a great deal of the traditional American songbook, Timmy has created his own brand of “outlaw.” Keeping a lighthearted confidence while singing about the kinds of things we're all thinking but not saying. Recorded in his hometown of American Fork, UT, Timmy The Teeth's latest release, Ain't That Bad (Aug '17), was produced and co-written with Joshua James, and offers a bold, humorous, and hooky follow up to TtT's debut LP, Just Another Day.

body.class_summary: East Forest will create a live soundscape as Tony G beautifully weaves a well sequenced class ending in an extended savasana. All levels are welcome and look forward to seeing you.
body.name: Tony G
body.class_title: Yoga for the People with Tony G and live music by East Forest
body.bio:
Tony’s devotion to the path of yoga and self-expression fills his classes with both knowledge and intensity, while his big heart lends sweetness and compassion. His classes are infused with biomechanics, philosophy, breath work and often times live music. He pulls inspiration from his diverse artistic background and this, in turn, creates the vision and voice for his teachings. Tony views teaching as a live collaboration that allows him to explore all the different aspects of himself as well as a way to guide people on their own inner and outer journey. Tony’s greatest joy is in helping to awaken new students’ passion for yoga and to see new and seasoned practitioners find deep freedom and self-expression in the context of a safe and loving environment.

Workshops:
Friday, 12:00-1:30 PM and Saturday 11:15 AM-12:45 PM
Yoga for the People
Music By East Forest
East Forest will create a live soundscape as Tony G beautifully weaves a well sequenced class ending in an extended savasana. All levels are welcome and look forward to seeing you.

body.name: Electric Coconut
body.bio: Electric Coconut's jazzy jams keep you movin' and groovin'. Hailing from Boise, Idaho, this 6-piece band features some brass and a whole lot of sass. Their first LP will arrive in 2018 so keep your ears peeled for some Coconut crackin' soon!

body.name: Frankie Simone
body.bio: Rising pop powerhouse Frankie Simone is paving a new and unapologetic path for her original pop music in Portland, Oregon. She has a unique take on top 40 pop world with an authentic message: be you, do you, and do it BIG. Simone uses her vocal talents to cut through the usual lyrical content of pop music. As a queer woman of color, she is fueled by a calling to express her story without inhibition. Inspiring messages abound, but bump these jams at the club, and you won’t be able to help dancing. Listen to the words, and your mind will follow.

body.name: Gabrielle Nelson
body.bio: Gabrielle Nelson is a poet and writer of animal fiction. She won second place in Boise Weekly’s 2018 fiction 101 contest for her short story “Boundaries.” Her 101-word story “Pirate Queen,” was featured in 101 Words first print magazine. Her first publication, “Thirst,” was published in Writer’s in the Attic’s 2016 Water anthology.  During the summers of 2013 & 2014 she had the wonderful opportunity to intern at The Cabin—A Center for Readers and Writers, where she was inspired by the teaching-writers and their students. Gabrielle is a graduate of the College of Idaho. She is currently a horse wrangler for Enchantment Equitreks in New Mexico.

body.name: The French Tips
body.bio: Formed in late 2016 out of a love of dance and rage, this disco occult band consists of Rachel Couch (Desert Graves, The Kitchen), Angela Heileson (Desert Graves, Dirt Russell) and Ivy Merrell (Dark Swallows, Get Wet Plus).

body.name: Connan Mockasin

song.title: I'm the Man, That Will Find You

body.bio: New Zealand via Paris/London pop sprite Connan Mockasin follows up the widely acclaimed oddball-psych of 2010’s Forever Dolphin Love. Caramel boasts a unique brand of mutated, lustrous soul that was almost wholly self-recorded over a month in a Tokyo hotel room. Described by Clash Music as “a true cosmonaut of inner space,” the new album explores different regions of Mockasin’s singular galaxy, guided by his truly adventurous songwriting that favors reconfigured pop structures with a skewed funk sensibility. If Caramel wasn’t enough, Mockasin has also been writing more material for Charlotte Gainsbourg after penning the exquisite “Out Of Touch” for the actress/singer’s 2012 mini-album, Stage Whisper. It’s another sign that Mockasin is going places, but at his own pace – just as Caramel suggests the process of melting and taking on a new shape, a new taste. That is the true sound of Connan Mockasin.

body.name: The Shrine by St. Terrible and HOUD
body.bio:
"What is worth worshiping?"

Combining elements of live dance and music with structural art, The Shrine is an intimate immersive experience created with the intention of exploring the deeper edges of human existence. Join us as we explore and celebrate life at it's darkest and most joyful moments. 

Come experience The Shrine, and consider what it is that brings you into connection with the human experience.

Presented by St. Terrible and House Of Upside Down

body.name: Moaning
body.bio:
Los Angeles-band Moaning is the abrasive post-punk trio comprised of Sean Solomon, Pascal Stevenson, and Andrew MacKelvie.  The three initially met as teenagers while growing up in the San Fernando Valley, and immediately developed a kinship through Los Angeles’s local music scene. The three began regularly frequenting DIY institutions like The Smell and Pehrspace, eventually selling out dozens of their shows at both venues with their first few bands.

From the sentimental to catastrophic, hiding meek and introspective lyrics within powerful droning dance songs, the music Moaning makes also gives sonic nods to some of the band’s musical heroes like New Order, Broadcast, and Slowdive. 

Moaning’s fervent songs are born out of the member’s experiences with love and distress, creating a sound uniquely dark and sincere. This is evidenced in the band’s early version (and video) of their track, “The Same.” The three went into their home studio to record the song and subsequently decided to shoot a music video for the track. Moaning was tipped off about a house that was about to be demolished nearby, and had quickly assembled a group of friends and filmed them taking turns destroying the estate. Meanwhile, Solomon, Stevenson, and MacKelvie tried their best to perform the song amongst the chaos. The video’s budget was limited to the sledgehammers, spray paint, and a case of beer they provided for the friends who were invited to cause havoc, which emphasizes Moaning’s desire to make as much impact with as few resources as possible. The track’s skidding percussion and toned back vocals gave merely a glimmer of the target Moaning aimed to hit with their sound.

body.name: Elena Tomorowitz
body.bio: Elena Tomorowitz earned a PhD in Literature and Creative Writing from The University of Southern Mississippi's Center for Writers. She has work appearing in magazines such as Guernica, The Collagist, Hayden's Ferry Review, Fugue, Thin Air Magazine, and others. She lives in Boise where she is a writer, MBA student, and business consultant at Hewlett Packard Inc.

body.name: Chatterbots: Build Your Own Secure Chatbot
body.bio: Build-A-Bot—Brought to you by Forsta, a Secure Messaging Software Company. Build your own secure chatbot that runs on a Raspberry Pi. In this workshop, you'll build your own custom, end-to-end encrypted chatbot on a Raspberry Pi that you get to take home with you! We'll also talk about how to use the Pi to build a DIY IoT device in your home. Leave the workshop with your own customizable secure chatbot, and a Raspberry Pi!

body.name: Heidi Kraay
body.bio:
Playwright Heidi Kraay examines the connection between brain and body, seeking empathy with fractured characters. Writing across disciplines and training in diverse theater vocabularies gives her tools to live better making art. Her plays, including How To Hide Your Monster, Rajpurr: Tale of a Tiger, New Eden, DIRT (co-devised), Kilgore, CloudMelt and Ways Not to Drown, have recently been presented in Boise, regionally and in NYC through Boise Contemporary Theater, the National Winter Playwrights Retreat & Workshop, id Theater, Seven Devils Playwrights Conference, Campfire Theatre Festival, 8 in 48 Idaho and HomeGrown Theatre. Heidi is a founding artistic associate for Migration Theory, a physical art company (for which she co-devised SuperSecretSiteSpecificSomething in 2015) and is working on their 2018 production of small matters. Heidi holds an MFA in Creative Inquiry, Interdisciplinary Arts from California Institute of Integral Studies and is a member of the Dramatists Guild of America.

Join Heidi for a workshop geared toward writers 12+ at Rediscovered Books, 180 N 8th St, Boise, ID, Saturday, 3/24, 4:00-5:30, FREE and open.

Here are the details - Writing the Space Between Words

In this multi-sensory experience connecting body, mind and environment, discover what we can learn from time and space as writers and performing artists. We’ll work with our senses, memory and external text to unlock new stories and experiment with how we share them: exploring on our feet, recording on the page and playing with how those words play in the space between us. Create short, theatrical pieces you can develop further for stage or print as a writer for performance – whether you’re a playwright, songwriter, performance poet or something completely uncategorized. All levels of writing and performance experience welcome, ages 12 and up.

Bring a notebook and writing utensils.

body.name: Kid Dakota
body.bio:
Kid Dakota is the musical moniker of Darren Jackson. Formed in 1999, Kid Dakota released two albums on LOW's Chairkicker's Union - So Pretty (2002), and The West is the Future (2004) - and three albums on Graveface Records - A Winner's Shadow (2008), Listen to the Crows As They Take Flight (2011), and Denervation (2018).

Darren is a multi-instrumentalist, composer, engineer, teacher, and producer. He owns and operates Shortman Studio in Northeast Minneapolis. In addition to creating and recording music, he is currently a Ph.D. student in ASPECT (Alliance for Social, Political, Ethical, and Cultural Thought) at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. His areas of research are early twentieth-century avant-garde film, film theory, and philosophy.

body.name: Digging In: Stories of Global Flavors
body.bio:
Join restauranteurs from around the globe as they recount stories of their favorite dishes and explain their culinary and cultural significance. Co-presented with Storyfort. 

Moderator: Scott Ki, Edible Idaho

Panelists:

*Chef E (Sararak Sapiro) was raised in a small village in Northeastern Thailand, learning about the traditional and therapeutic uses of Thai herbs from her father. She is the chef and owner of Lime and a Coconut, which caters, hosts pop-up dinners and can be found at the Capital City Public Market.

*Kibrom Milash and his wife, Tirhas Hailu, own Kibrom's Ethiopian & Eritrean Restaurant on State Street. Originally from Eritrea in East Africa, they moved to a refugee camp in Ethiopia for five years until they moved to Boise in 2013.

*Chef Ratna Subba arrived in Boise in 2012, and has since shared his passion for introducing others to Nepalese cuisine by opening a food truck named Darjeeling MoMo in 2015.

body.name: Bobbi Prentice
body.bio: My name is Bobbi Prentice and I have been rockin' it as a lead bartender at Cowgirls in Kuna for 9 years now.  During that time I have achieved Bachelor's Degrees in English Literature, Communications, Theater Arts and Non-Profit Management.  Bartending is an environment ripe with story opportunities and most of my stories involve some element of the bar atmosphere.  It has also allowed me the freedom to be involved in many non-profit ventures as well as start my own travel blog.  Realisticguidetoabucketlist.com.  I look forward to sharing my stories at Storyfort!

body.name: Secret Sauce - How to Pitch Your Tech Story
body.bio: Boise transplant Jennifer Kite-Powell (Forbes) will be moderating a panel on how to get your newest innovation featured by top tech publications. Panel participants include Neel Patel (Wired), Alejandro Rojas (HuffPost) and Chris Longo (Den of Geek).

body.name: Alien Boy
body.bio: Self identified Gay Goth band from Portland, OR; Alien Boy plays a endearing blend of emotional 80's post punk and 90's alt rock about gay heartbreak and big feelings. Started in 2014 by Sonia Weber and Derek Mcniel they put out their first EP "Never Getting Over It" followed by their  2016 "Stay Alive" EP. Their debut full length will be coming out sometime in mid 2018.

body.name: Bad Licks
body.bio: With the release of their first single "Set Them on fire" Bad Licks became one of Denver's most talked about rock and roll bands. With a hard driving rhythm section, dissonant guitars, and scratch lead vocals, Bad Licks evokes a combination of late 60's Detroits with 1977 New York punk.

body.name: Yardsss ∅∀‡
body.bio: Yardsss tends toward the dark and droning and bombastic, with heady, swelling orchestrations.  Perhaps because human voices appear so rarely and the music is so evocative, it occasionally brings to mind Emeralds' Does It Look Like I'm Here?  It doesn't take many listens to understand that Krueger is breaking boundaries not for the sake of being (or seeming) transgressive, but to make sounds that awaken actual feelings—uplifting, inspiring emotions. - Portland Mercury

body.name: The Pan Handles
body.bio:
Born from local songwriter collective Thistledown, this trio has emerged as a musical force layering acoustic sounds into patterns that often rearrange themselves several times within a single track. Gypsy, folk, blues, and bluegrass are among the genres you'll hear from the mouths and instruments of these seasoned musicians and songwriters.

Heather, Neal and Bennett have performed together at Sawtooth Valley Gathering and Treefort Music Fest, and they've shared stages with Jay Cobb Anderson Band, Jeff Crosby and the Refugees, The Young Dubliners, Shook Twins and members of Yonder Mountain String Band and Old Crow Medicine Show. Bennett and Heather cut their chops playing in northwest folk projects The Jackalope Saints, Stoneseed, Jonathan Warren and the Billy Goats, and sharing stages with traveling acts from across the west like Elephant Revival, Blackberry Bush String Band and the Sweet Lillies. Neal Goldberg brings a strong, international background in blues and rock, relocating from Singapore where he headlined a blues revue six nights a week. Neal's an accomplished guitar player who attended Berklee College of Music for guitar performance and has been taking the Boise music scene by storm since his arrival in 2016.

body.name: Groggy Bikini
body.bio:
A high energy, spirited "dorky punk rock band" fronted by Jon Hale (of longtime local new wave band the Commonauts).
Jon is from Boise and moved to Seattle in the late 80's. He and his band Gorilla toured with many of the great bands of the punk/early grunge years. He formed Groggy Bikini in Seattle, and when he moved home to Boise recruited a couple young punk rockers, some old  Rock-rockers for the Boise Lineup. 
Jon and his Wife, Tracey, spend much of their time volunteering at the Boise Hive, a local non-profit inexpensive rehearsal space which also provides "mental health services for musicians in need". 
Current lineup of Groggy Bikini: Jon Hale- Guitar, Vocals Bob Waller- Bass, Vocals Danny Brown- Guitar Jay Hensley- Drums Mollie Williams- Vocals, Dancing Andy Agenbroad- Guitar

body.name: Joy Young
body.bio: Joy Young is a performance and teaching spoken word artist based in Phoenix, Az. Their poetry and workshops, much of which centers on transgressing borders, entering topics pertaining to social justice through poetic personal narratives has been featured on Button Poetry and Everyday Feminism as well as on stages and in colleges and classrooms across the country. Joy is a co-founder of Off the Page-- a monthly recurring workshop and open mic at Wasted Ink Zine Distro that seeks to build connection and community within Phoenix's diverse literary and performance communities. Additionally, Joy is an editorial board member for Rinky Dink Press. Joy's work seeks to cultivate strong personal narratives within a larger social justice context. They believe these personal narratives should be a driving force for healing ourselves and the world around us— that they are a doorway through which we should consciously enter the world of social justice in hopes of creating understanding, connection and making substantive change.

body.name: Morning Altars
body.bio:
DAY SCHILDKRET is internationally known for Morning Altars and has inspired tens of thousands of people of all ages from all over the world to forage, build and be awed with Earth Art.

Morning Altars is igniting an international movement of art, workshops and a spiritual practice that renews and redeems our relationship to nature, creativity and impermanence. With over 57k followers on Instagram, over 25k on Facebook and work- shops and installations worldwide, Morning Altars is bringing ephemeral art to the collective human imagination.

The first Morning Altars’ book is being published Fall 2018 by The Countryman Press an imprint of W.W. Norton.

body.name: The Seshen
body.bio: The Seshen is a San Francisco Bay Area-based six-piece led by singer/lyricist Lalin St. Juste and bassist/producer Akiyoshi Ehara. Their forward-thinking sound combines synthesizers, drum machines, live percussion, and entrancing harmonies to create an unmistakable fusion of R&B, synth-pop, and electronic music. St. Juste and Ehara are joined by four remarkable bandmates to create their multidimensional music: drummer Chris Thalmann, keyboard/synth player Mahesh Rao, percussionist Mirza Kopelman, and sampler Kumar Butler. They take inspiration from across the musical spectrum; their individual influences range from recognizable artists (Erykah Badu, Jai Paul, James Blake, Radiohead, and Broadcast) to genres and eras that don’t initially appear to fit together (hip hop, indie rock, early electronica, and 70’s dub). Their unique alchemy of seemingly disparate sounds has led fans and critics alike to describe the band as defying categorization.

body.name: DJ Gladwell
body.bio: DJ Gladwell has been obsessed with hip-hop music since the early 80’s and began tinkering with djing and beat-making during his college years in the 90’s. After moving to Boulder Colorado in 2001, surrounded by world-class record stores and a thriving local hip-hip music scene, his obsession for progressive indie-rap/electronic music became ignited like high-grade explosives. Gladwell met some talented young high school kids and formed the Crew known as the Whiskey Blanket. DJ Gladwell was spinning regularly around Boulder, making beats and building friendships with the many underground rap groups who regularly toured through town, right up to the moment where he was run over in the street by a speeding BMW. Faced with major leg and spinal injuries and what would be over a year-long recovery, Gladwell had no other option but to move back to Boise to recuperate in his parents home. While recovering, Gladwell noticed that none of the amazing touring hip-hop acts who were performing every week in Colorado, were doing shows in Boise. That is when he decided that instead of moving back to Boulder, he would stay in Boise and devote his energies to the goal of trying to bring more independent touring hip-hop acts to town. If you were, for example, one of the 28 people who saw Heiroglyphics play at the Blues Bouquet in 2005, you probably know DJ Gladwell. Gladwell has performed on-stage with countless underground rap groups, toured with Pharcyde and Josh Martinez, has produced a beat or two and while he might not be the BEST DJ in Boise... or even the 5th best... he does have an amazing record collection and when he takes the time to put together a set... it can be pretty dope.

body.name: ALLEYS
body.bio: ALLEYS is a multi instrumental musical project founded in 2013 by artist and musician Jacob Diaz. Combing Post Rock and Hip Hop aesthetics to create intricate and moody Instrumental songs, ALLEYS debut  E.P (Hurry Up To Relax 2014) and LP debut ( Future Self 2017) pay homage to 90's Hip Hop and Indie Rock with soulful melodies and complex rhythms.

body.name: Preakedness
body.bio: Preakedness makes music to match that fugue state between sleep and life where reality slowly unravels into many different threads of varying absurdity. Synthesizers, electric pianos, and found audio roll alongside bombastic drums and fuzzy melodic bass lines to form songs that can move between strange groovers to noisey post-punk rages.

body.name: Melanie Billark
body.bio: Melanie is really interested in community engagement, public art, and site specific interventions. Being apart of Treefort Music Fest is an incredible experience for her, to be able to show her  work in another country and be able to interact with new audiences, network with other artists, and be apart of a larger culture. She is looking forward to see how other cities interact and perceive her work in a new setting.

body.name: The Dirty Moogs
body.bio:
We are the Dirty Moogs, from Boise, Idaho, probably*, and we have major plans for Treefort 2018 to make performances and dancing for all of our new friends! We can't wait to meet pals that we love so much and fully endorse their life choices!** 

Even though we care mostly about making parties and dancing and lasers, we think, perhaps, it is time to say something with more emotional words for our 19th*** Treefort appearing. Unfortunately, we maybe got distracted and wrote a song about karate and baseball cards in outer space for  your disco dancing pleasure!

Additionally, while we don't want to make namings, the Wolfgang in the band who is closest in height to a basketball pointbucket has been ignoring his behavior management case worker and saying funny things about the other Wolfgangs. What sort of response could the other Wolfgangs have in mind? Will it be at the Dirty Moogs' Treefort 2018 show? Will it involve live animals, accountants, or confetti cannons?

Please! Come dancing and find out!

*The Dirty Moogs are from Boise, Germany.
**The Dirty Moogs do not fully endorse your life choices.
*** The Dirty Moogs have not appeared at Treefort Music Festival 18 times previously.
****No accountants will be employed at the Dirty Moogs Treefort 2018 show.

body.name: Jonathan Evison
body.bio: Jonathan Evison is the New York Times Bestselling author of All About Lulu, West of Here, The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving, This is Your Life, Harriet Chance! and Lawn Boy. He has written for The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, NPR, and Salon. Sherman Alexie has called Evison the most honest white man alive.

body.name: Brent Kuecker
body.bio: Brent Kuecker is a Yoga educator and copywriter as well as a professional musician. As a bass player and devotional singer, Brent has played bass for kirtan and mantra music for 16 years. Brent has toured internationally with Kirtan artists Shantala, Dave Stringer and Sheela Bringi.

body.name: Prom Queen
body.bio:
Seattle’s glitter gloom band, Prom Queen, is comprised of eight virtuoso musicians. Fronted by the bouffant wearing vocalist Leeni Queeno, the group includes two electric guitar players (the eerie Ben Von Wildenhaus and prodigious Jason Goessl), bassist (Birch Pereira), saxophonist (Jon Sampson), drummer (Tom Meyers) and a duo of drag queen backup singers (Joelle and Evonne). 

While tracks from the band have been featured in outlets like IndieWire, KEXP 90.3 FM, and Seattle’s City Arts magazine, Prom Queen’s latest release, “Doom-Wop,” is the group’s most complete and acclaimed album. A theatrical record featuring songs about going blonde, the end of the world, mania and loneliness, the work is brought to life when Prom Queen takes the stage. Imbuing qualities of haunted Americana, Prom Queen, very much in the lineage of John Waters and Twin Peaks, shows that they’re equal parts nostalgia and numinous mystery.

body.name: Kevin Baker
body.bio: As a bartender and distiller, I have worked all over the world from Angostura in Trinidad to Whistle Pig in Vermont. I enjoy a wide variety of custom and culture that I bring to every expression, I'm very glad to be home in Boise and to have the opportunity to share some of my experience.

body.name: Failure Machine
body.bio:
Soul, baby. Failure Machine has somehow channeled the ghosts of late great soul/R&B artists, dirtied them up and electrified them. 
Wielding guitar, drums, vocals and sax, they give a grungy throwback to the old days of Stax Records, making what could be a familiar and even trite sound into something unique and exciting. 
These Reno boys (and girl) prove they’ve got chops with their party-trained live shows. Just be ready to get pretty sweaty.

body.name: Built To Spill
body.bio:
Since their first release in 1993, Ultimate Alternative Wavers, Built To Spill have become one of the defining forces in American independent (in every sense of the word) modern rock: 

“Martsch and his bandmates continue to make dense, driving rock with good old-fashioned chords and melodies, and for this we should all be grateful.”  -- Rolling Stone

“Doug Martsch and his band have perfected the witty, melodic and poignant articulation of longing, heartache, alienation, spite, scorn and just about anything else you care to imagine.”  - Spin.Com

“The solo, perhaps is not cool…There are, of course exceptions to this long-developing trend. Chief among the standard-bearers is Built To Spill.” – Associated Press

“… As if no one ever doubted the beauty of a long, slow-building solo…Doug Martsch applies his high voice and his earnest intelligence to songs that address both his private conflicts and his political convictions.”  -- The New York Times

Built To Spill have proven they are most certainly built to last.” – Nylon

“Subtly excellent an obviously influential. If you’re not excited about Built To spill, you’re living in the past.” – Magnet Magazine

“The Boise, Idaho band has filled the space where flannel meets Birkenstocks. Their jangly head trips placed them somewhere between Sonic Youth and Luna on the indie-rock circuit, but they’ve also wooed Deadheads…Unique, virtuosic musicianship.”  -- Spin

body.name: Bodie

song.title: Wuf Ticket - The Key (Bodie's Re-edit Dub Version)

body.bio: Boise's own oldest and original house DJ instrumental in creating the house and techno scene in Boise in the late 80's and early 90's. He began spinning at private house parties and the original Crazy Horse and was the first DJ hired and to be given residency at the Neurolux. He went on to a successful recording career in Europe as a solo disco artist and as part of the Belgian duo Hustler & Gloss. He has since worked as an international DJ playing Nudisco sets in Amsterdam, New York, Brussels and Nice and is still featured in radio programs in Melbourne and Vienna. He has been well recieved by international disco artists and DJ's as well as charting in London for his works under multiple record labels. He has most recently put his roots back in Boise and has been once again featured at Nuerolux and at the Red Feather Lounge. His sound is Nudisco Boogie Funk & Rock focused on mostly European, New York and Chicago hits of the late 70's and early 80's. He specializes in hand tailored re-edits and  broadcasting heartfelt classics of analog to digital sounds unique to that time frame.

body.name: Spiritual Warfare and the Greasy Shadows

song.artist_name: Spiritual Warfare and the Greasy Shadows
song.title: Viewfinder

body.bio: New exotica, garage Bollywood with heavy do-wop influence and crooner vocals.  Elements of world and darkness.

body.name: Grayson County Burn Ban
body.bio:
Coming together from an array of Denver bands, Grayson County Burn Ban has a sound that could be described as something when "Uncle Tupelo and Nirvana play songs around the same campfire" or characterized as "a group [that makes] listeners think and also makes them lift their glasses [for] some great dive-bar drinking anthems." 
With their new full-length album "Better Neighbor" out in January 2018, GCBB is focuses on a circadian portrait of their generation. Songs like "Be Here Now" and "Friends" accentuate the social complexities of living in the public sphere, while such songs as "Way It Was" and "Nothing to Lose" tip their hat to nostalgia, but only as a starting point to grow and learn from.
Their sound is part acoustic folk and part shoe-gaze rock - with elements of honky-tonk thrown in to keep you dancing. As an album, "Better Neighbor" flows like a bouncing brook; but it may be hard to compartmentalize their sound into a certain genre. Fortunately, they have done this for you and proudly state that Grayson County Burn Ban plays "Campfire Country Rock".

body.name: Tyto Alba
body.bio: Denver four-piece Tyto Alba melds singer/songwriter Melanie Steinway’s fingerpicking folk background and heartfelt vocals with shoegazey texture and post-rock dynamics to form an indie-rock project reminiscent of modern acts like Daughter, Alvvays and Big Thief.  Tyto’s founding members Melanie Steinway and Matt Rossi, after meeting at a singer-songwriter showcase, breathed life into the band as Steinway’s former folk outfit dissolved. They were later joined by long-time friends Danny DiMarchi and Andrew Bair, to complete the band’s current lineup. Tyto Alba self-released their sophomore EP, 'In Our Own Time', in March of 2017.

body.name: Elizabeth Almanza
body.bio: Elizabeth Almanza is a Boise State University student in the Masters of Social Work program. She received her undergraduate degree in Sociology with an emphasis in Criminal Justice and a Minor in Political Science. She has been an activist for intersectional feminism for six years now and in 2016 became a community organizer.  She has worked with PODER and Adelante SE Idaho where she has been actively advocating for immigrant’s rights

body.name: 208 ensemble
body.bio: 208 ensemble is a dynamic, multi-instrumental ensemble specializing in the performance of today’s most innovative chamber music. Established in Boise, Idaho, its members are dedicated to exploring interdisciplinary collaboration, providing a platform for emerging and underrepresented composers, and cultivating enthusiasm within diverse audiences for a brand of music that exists where the refinement of classical performance meets the visceral energy of a rock concert.

body.name: Dave Butler
body.bio:
I’m a novelist living in the Rocky Mountain west.
